name: Legio VI Constantiniani
description:
Legio VI Constantiniani is a set of miniatures wargames rules aimed to allow large battles of Roman Late Imperial period (AD 250-600) to be resolved relatively quickly. It's meant for 6mm figures but could easily be adapted to larger (or smaller!) figures.

The rules are derived from the same designer's Comitatus set of Dark Ages rules, but slimmed down to allow larger battles to be fought in less time. Troops are classed a relatively small number of troop types with minimal differentiation based on equipment; the focus is on troop quality and, especially, generals' limited means of controlling their forces.

The rules are freely available from the designer's webpage, along with sister sets covering adjoining periods:

Legio VI Julia Augusta, for 100 BC to AD 250
Legio VI Macedonica, for 400-100 BC
Legio VI Diadochi, for Alexander and the Successors

name: Indie Dev
description:
In IndieDev, players are independent video game developers trying to earn prestige in the game industry by creating and releasing critically acclaimed game projects. Players will juggle the many aspects of running an independent video game company, including completing side jobs to gain extra income; taking courses to improve abilities; figuring out how to afford marketing; investing in marketing in order to increase market visibility. Did the game bomb on release? Players should make the most of the situation, never giving up. Did the game earn critical success and sell? Players must take that hard-earned cash and use it productively; otherwise players will end up struggling once again.
Players that work through the multiple challenges effectively will triumph within one of the most challenging but rewarding industries. The player that earned the most prestige will win this game and of course win at life (Mostly win, they still will devote most of their waking life to their next project).

—description from the designer

name: Liar Battleship
description:
Each player leads a battleship fleet. The object of the game is destroy all of your opponent's ships. In each turn player fire cannon to opponent's fleet, opponent announce hit or miss, but they can lie.But this game is also suitable for those are not good at lying, because all lying ablity is given by ship itself.
player number: 2~4
game time：15 minutes per player

Each player has 6 ships and 6 empty sea cards,place their 12 cards face down to form a 4x3 formation
Each player on his turn has 2 actions.
For each action, player has 3 options
1) Attack directly: attack 1 of opponent's card. The opponent look at his card. If it is a ship, he say “Hit”, if it is not a ship, he say “Miss”. Put “Hit” or “Miss” token on that card.
2）Attack adjacently: attack a space between two cards. The opponent look at both his cards. If either of them is a ship, he say “Hit”; if neither of them is a ship, he say “Miss”. Place “Hit” or “Miss” token between margin of two cards.
Whenever a ship's life point is equal of below 0 (life points on card minus “Hit” on the ship card and around the ship card), the ship is sunk. Ship's owner shall flip the card face up.
3) Radar scan. Scan one cross point of two margin lines. Opponent look at his cards around scan point.Opponent count all this cards current life point and say that number. Put a radar scan number token on that point.

maybe you think attack adjacently is more powerful,but may ship's ability is against adjacent attack. For example, submarine dodge all adjacent attack and count it as Miss.

"11:58" is a hand-management/voting card game with social deduction elements. Players take the roles of agents during a conflict between two fictional superpowers.

On each turn a global event card is flipped. Every global event card reveals a crisis which can tick the doomsday clock (represented by eight scoring cards) closer or further from humanity's destruction - these global events also affect the relationship between the two superpowers. Players vote to determine the outcome of each global event card.

With these votes players must balance two (sometimes conflicting) goals - players must both ensure humanity's survival and complete their own unique hidden agenda.

The game ends when the doomsday clock reads entirely red (signalling humanity's destruction) or entirely blue (signalling humanity's salvation). At this point each player reveals their hidden objective; players who have completed all their objectives win the game.

-description from designer
categories: Card Game, Negotiation, Party Game, Spies/Secret Agents
mechanics: Deduction, Hand Management, Team-Based Game, Voting

name: WAPLEworlds
description:
ARE YOU AVERAGE ENOUGH TO BE A WAPLE?
You, solo, or with up to three friends take, the role of a member of the worst wrestling family ever, The Waples! Play as Biff the scared wrestler, Spiff the rubber sword-wielding teen, his mom Ivanna and her charms, Randi the out-of-work model, Yodel the chef, or many others.

WAPLEworlds is similar to a dungeon crawler game in that players move their characters, members of the Waple Family, around an 8x8 tile, while encountering Bad Guys and exploring exotic locations such as Pepe's Motor Lodge and the Scam and Save Pawn Shop. Yes, it is comedy themed.

The starter box includes eight playable Waple figures and their Hero Cards, 25 Bad Guy Cards and their standees, over 40 item cards, over 20 Something Happened cards, Mission cards, 12 location tiles a WAPLEworld "newsletter" with rules and pre-made scenarios, 10 dice and money, damage and level tokens.

During a player's turn, he moves his character and can perform an action: search, confront a Bad Guy, use a card, or enter a building. Confronting a Bad Guy can mean to either fight him, bribe him, or run away like a chicken.

Confrontations with Bad Guys: Fighting, Bribing and Running Away, are all controlled by dice rolls based on the stats listed on both the Hero's and the Bad Guys cards.

After that, if not in combat, the player will draw a Something Happened card and execute what it states. If the player enters a location he rolls a die to see if a Mission is currently available there. If it is then he may try to resolve it to save that area by placing the appropriate new tile and Bad Guys onto that tile with the Waple and any that join him.

The third phase of a turn is for any Bad Guy that the player is controlling to either move peacefully or attack the player.

A game can be played with a simple one tile and one mission limit to up to five tiles and over a dozen missions completed, based on the time limit the player wants. Missions increase in difficulty by placing more Bullies (minions) along with the Big Shot (boss) on the Mission tiles.

On the first tile everyone starts at level 0. After the tile's mission is cleared, all Waples level up and can enhance their skills in the way the player wants, increasing dice rolled for certain stats. Bad Guys level up and roll one more die per level as well. On the second tile the Waples search and complete two missions. The game progresses as such until the final Scenario Mission has been conquered.

-description from designer
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Modular Board, Role Playing, Tile Placement, Variable Player Powers

name: Ozark Air Travel Game
description:
Made by PrestoMagix, this game was given out on Ozark Airline flights for a limited time. Ozark was bought by TWA in 1986, who in 2001 was acquired by American Airlines.

The game is simple and uses colorform-like stickers of airplanes, servicing equipment and airline personnel on a three-fold nicely drawn landscape board. One to six players place the stickers to crate a collective travel plan on Ozark. In game mechanic terms, this is a very early cooperative game!

name: Scream Aim Fire: WW2 Wargaming Rules
description:
Scream Aim Fire is a set of miniatures wargame rules for the Second World War.

Before play, a deck is created with a card for each vehicle or squad of infantry. In each turn, cards are drawn, one at a time, to determine which unit attempts to activate next. A unit that fails to active has to take a shock and awe test to avoid being eliminated! A unit that does successfully activate, or one that fails but survives the shock and awe test, gets three dice to divide between movement, loading, and firing. Fire is resolved by a mixture of dice rolls and chit draws.

In the interests of a quick and simple game, differentiation between different unit types is minimal: all tanks are the same, for example.
categories: Book, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Infinite Evil
description:
Infinite Evil is a sci-fi RPG miniatures board game for 1-4 players in development by Intfury games studio.
Several mutually hostile groups are locked on a transport spaceship with a broken main engine. The game features 4 squads. Each squad has its own goal. The game ends by accomplishing this goal or by destroying all other players.
There are 9 characters in a squad. A player loses if all his characters die or another player completes his goal. Basically players move in turns, trying to take a profitable position and not to give another player to go to the key mission elements that he was unable to achieve his goal. By completing missions, a player acquires money, resources and new battle cards. A battle takes place if players are near, within one cell.
A player can accumulate 30 cards in the deck, but he can use only 10 in a battle. A battle consists of 1 round. All battle cards have a description of the action. Players count the number of points (written on the cards) at the end of the round. Who have more points - the winner. But you need to take into account the ability of the cards, if any. Card abilities are diverse: plus to protect, to attack, and so on. The winner gets money or a new card. The loser loses the character who participated in the battle.
Cards:
Special cards has description of their action and no points.
Special cards are very powerful. One card can cause damage to 3 cards or, for example, to revive your squad.
Battle cards has description of their action and there are points on them. Battle cards places to battlefield board which divided in three rows (for each player).
The characters are divided into 3 groups. Each group placed in a row.
1st row - melee group.
2nd row - middle range group.
3rd row - long range group.
Each row corresponds to the icon: melee, medium range, long range. A card can be placed to the correct type of row only.
A melee character can only be placed in a melee row and attacks enemy's cards in a 1st row. Also melee group can add points for your group in another row.
Middle range character can be placed in a middle range row only. Middle range group can attack enemy's cards in 1st and 2nd rows.
Long range character can be placed in a long range row only and attacks enemy's cards in all three rows. Points are counted at the end of the battle.
Release of the game is scheduled for February 2019.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Role Playing, Team-Based Game

name: Pacific 1942 Islands
description:
In front of you lies the Pacific Ocean and your goal is to gain twelve victory points by conquering the islands and sinking enemy ships.

Pacific 1942 Islands is the version of the core game Pacific 1942 Admiral created in 2018.

New scenario. The new goal of the game.

The main changes:

Unlimited range of aircraft, the speed of the ships does not depend on their strength.
Aircraft ships begin the game off the harbour.
Japanese Admiral starts the game with a massive strike on Pearl Harbor.
No new ships can be repaired or built during the game.

—description from the publisher

name: Yesterday's War: The Salvage
description:
Yesterday's War: The Salvage is a small box worker placement game set in a sci-fi post-apocalypse.

It’s been fifty years since the War ended, and two hundred and thirty since the War began. The city of Elysium stands bright and shining in a sea of ashes and rubble. It's the largest city on Earth and the only place where air can be safely breathed.

Everything in Elysium is built from recycled parts from the War. You and up to three other players are salvage workers who wander the wasteland in search of old war machines that can be scrapped for parts. Each salvage worker has four mechs to gather resources and a special ability that gives them an advantage in the game. Salvage workers will fulfill contracts, achieve objectives, earn rewards, and fight raiders - all in the pursuit of sweet, sweet victory points.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Push Your Luck, Variable Player Powers, Worker Placement

name: Grantara: The Breath of Evil
description:
A board game where 1-2 players can play for the master of evil, while the other 1-2 players will resist them, playing for the forces of good, exploring different locations and picking the loot from the defeated forces of evil.

The game is designed for 2-4 players, where players will need to make tactical and strategic decisions to achieve their goals. Each player will be able to choose whom he will play for monsters or squad.

In this game, the player has to wisely approach the selection of the setup squad, and the player managing the monster must predict the actions of the enemy in which the quantitative advantage.

Playing for the squad player can choose one of the two factions (1st version) and hire a team for their wanderings through a dangerous and at the same time wonderful world of the game.

On his turn, the player of the squad(s) can explore the dungeon, engaging in battle with monsters, rotten squads of the evil master, and also collect treasures for winning in battle.

The master of evil on his turn can control monsters, send rotten squads, strengthen his power and in every possible way prevent the squads from surviving in the dungeon.

The game has unique mechanics and many nuances and features that turn each battle into challenges for each side.

The aim of the evil master is to collect a certain number of points, which is determined by the length of the adventure, after reaching the targets the opponents will be considered defeated.

The objective of the squad(s) is to pass the dungeon the length of which they choose at the beginning of the adventure, and also fulfill certain conditions on the last location.

The journey is considered complete when one of the parties fulfills its victory conditions.

name: Golden Islands
description:
"Golden Islands" - a gambling and fun game with easy rules for 2-4 players, age 8+, in which you take on the role of the captain of the ship. You will plow the ocean, exploring the islands and collecting gold coins. Of course, it will not do without battles with other captains! Despite the seeming simplicity, the game has many strategies and options for progress towards victory!

The goal of the game is collecting gold coins. To win, you need to collect more coins than other players.

On your turn you will travel between islands (you choose your way), fight with other players and, using dice, play different events (good or bad).

Turn sequence:

Players turn consists of three phases: moving, battle and event.

- Moving:
Move your pawn to any neighboring island (including any starting position). You can move only vertically or horizontally (orthogonally). If another player is already on the island, go to the battle phase. If the coin is on the island, pick it up and put it in front of you, then go to the event phase. If the island has neither a coin nor another player - go to the event phase.

- Battle:
If you moved to an island on which another player is already located, it means that you attacked him. Proceed to battle. Each player has three health markers that represent the state of your ship. The battle consists of a series of rounds - attacks. Both players roll one die each. The player, who has less value, gets damaged and turns over one of his health markers. If both players have the same values, the dice are thrown. Attack is repeated until one of the players turns his last, third, health marker - this player lost in this fight. After the end of the battle, the winner takes half of the coins from the loser (rounding up), and the loser returns to his starting position. Players reverse their health markers (repairs the ship). If the losing player does not have a single coin, the winner does not receive anything. This ends your turn.

- Event:
The event is played if you moved to an island on which there is no other player. Throw three dice and play the event which corresponds to the rolled dice value. This ends your turn.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Push Your Luck, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Repulse
description:
Repulse is a strategic card game consisting of 110 cards in 3 categories.

Is a good defense perhaps better than an attack? Can it be that you set up the tactic that leads to the goal? Are you ready?

Regardless of the game variant, it’s about being the first to defeat another army, so there are no more cards in front of an opponent. Always keep in mind that a wrong move may allow another player to win the game.

On your turn: Pick up two cards from the middle of the pile (or your own - depending on the game variant). You can attack with the face-up cards you face. You can play some action cards in your hand at any time (during an attack or while another player's turn takes place), others only when it's your turn. Once you've completed your attacks, you can reveal up to two face-down cards (or just one or none at all) and put them forward and replace them with hand cards. A maximum of 3 cards may be revealed and two cards face down. Think good of your strategy, because if you make too many attacks, you may not be able to defend yourself.

If an attack is made and it succeeds by higher value, both cards are placed on the open stack in the middle. If the attacker's army card value is lower than the defending card, the attack failed and the attack card is placed on the open stack in the middle.

—description from the designer

name: iCubo: Beige Cube promo
description: Beige promo cube for iCubo, with a different and unique puzzle configuration, not included in the base game.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Expansion for Base-game, Puzzle

name: iCubo: Fuchsia Cube promo
description: Fuchsia promo cube for iCubo, with a different and unique puzzle configuration, not included in the base game.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Expansion for Base-game, Puzzle

name: Mit Winnetou durch den Wilden Westen
description:
The players have to get their four figures fron their camp to one of the four Karl-May-Heroes: Winnetou, Nscho-Tschi, Old Shatterhand, Old Surehand. Movement is determined by two dice. The players can chose their way. On some spaces, event cards have to be drawn, which benefit or hinder the player.

—user summary
categories: American West, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based, Racing
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Repel Boarders
description:
Repel Boarders is a co-operative game for 2 to 6 players, you can take control of any number of the crew under Cpt Frank Smith in either one of the 9 included missions or if you prefer you can design your own! Although it’s not necessary to play the missions in order, should players wish to do so, a short narrative campaign is included in the game.

Gain weapons and armour from the chests scattered about the rooms on-board in your attempt to defeat the forces of space pirates that are attacking your ship. Missions have different objectives ranging from simply surviving a massive rush of pirates or escorting a VIP, to securing and defending vital parts of your ship.

Do you take on the role of a marine and attack the enemy head on or the role of medic or engineer and assist your fellow players in staying alive as wave after wave of blood thirsty pirates swarm the ship. Maybe you are the voice of command and as captain organise the others to follow you. Perhaps you want nothing more than 2 really big guns and a singular purpose and take the role of the robot. Maybe you are stealthy and tactical and can take on the pirates with nothing more than a chefs cleaver?

Each crew character starts with 3 action points which they can then spend freely on either moving, combat (melee or ranged) or on a special action, though only one special action maybe completed per person per turn. Special actions include healing, repairing doors, searching chests and trading etc.

Characters gain further actions and special abilities as the "Alert Level" on-board ship increases. While players start with a modicum of gear as play progresses they may pick up and trade items to suit either their own play style or that of the persona of the crew member they are playing.

Want to design your own campaign where you keep the items on your character and progress through your own customer scenarios? This is entirely possible with Repel Boarders modular double sided game tiles, corridor tiles and board connectors.

-description from publisher
mechanics: Action Points, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Role Playing

name: 異業種交流会 (Igyousyu Koryukai)
description:
User summary
異業種交流会 (Igyousyu Koryukai) is a Japanese deduction game.

This game is a deduction game without telling any lies. All players are attending a party and they are trying to let other players guess their occupation.

Questions will be revealed and all players must answer the same question. If only one single player managed to guess your occupation correctly, or you successfully guessed another player's occupation, you score 1 point. Whoever scores 2 point in a row is the winner of the game.

Publisher's summary
「異業種交流会」は嘘をつかなくてもいい正体隠匿系のゲームです。
プレイヤーはパーティの出席者となり、「自分の職業を他の人達に当ててもらおう」と考えます。しかし、同時にパーティの出席者はみんな照れ屋（シャイ）なので目立つのを嫌います。そこで、１人だけに自分の職業を当ててもらうことにしました。
このゲームはポイント制です。他の人の職業を当てた人、自分の職業を誰か１人だけに当ててもらった人に１ポイント入ります。連続して２ポイント取った人の勝ちです。
職業を当ててもらうには、「共通の質問」に答える必要があります。
categories: Card Game, Deduction, Negotiation, Party Game, Word Game

name: SIGLA: Fog & Rain
description:
SIGLA: Fog & Rain is an abstract card game where players move cards around the table in order to match secret point-scoring patterns in the players’ hands.

To win the game, you must be the first to play all the “Fog & Rain” cards from your hand to the play area in front of you by matching the patterns on the “SIGLA” cards.

—description from the designer

name: Pegboard Baseball
description:
Pegboard Baseball is a two-player themed game based on chance and probability. It is a game of luck and skill. Background knowledge of batter statistics is advantageous.
The game is handmade by the designer and consists of a 6 inch round piece of wood depicting a baseball diamond with cribbage peg holes around the baselines. Players are represented by team-colored cribbage pegs.

Pegboard Baseball can only be played when watching a baseball game on TV or at the stadium. The main reason you need to be watching a game is because fouls count for one peg movement. The best way to tally foul balls is by watching (or listening to) a game.

The score of the actual baseball game you are watching is not related to the score in Pegboard Baseball.
The movement of your peg depends entirely on what the batter does at the plate. Any contact between the bat and the ball is awarded by movement of your peg.

How to start:

Choose two pegs that represents your team and the opposing team. Place the two pegs on home plate.

The visiting team will start on the top of home plate (top of the innings) and continue around the bases on that line. The home team will start on the bottom on home plate (bottom of the innings).
What it looks like
when you are playing:

The person representing the batting team holds the pegboard.
Choose a goal for your game.
Possibilities include:

--Follow an entire game and the player with the most points, plus furthest distance, wins.
--Play for an equal number of innings and see whose peg traveled furthest (points plus distance). For example, prior to starting announce, “We are going to play for three innings.”

Peg movement depend on
what each batter does at the plate.

Foul Ball = 1 peg movement
When the batter hits the ball foul, out of play, that equals 1 peg movement.

Inplay Out = 2 peg movements
When a batter hits the ball in fair territory, but the batter is out. This includes pop flies and ground outs.

Single = 3 peg movements
When a batter hits the ball and is safe at 1st base.

Double = 4 peg movements
When the batter hits the ball and is safe at 2nd base. Also, ground rule doubles.

Triple = 5 peg movements
When the batter hits the ball and is safe at 3rd base.

Home run = 6
Two run homer = 12
Three run homer = 18
Grand Slam = 24
Bunt foul = 2
Bunt infield but out = 4
Bunt single = 6

Optional Scoring

Optional scoring prior to play:

For more peg movement: see directions
For less peg movements: see directions

Optional scoring during play:

Prior to any at-bat (or inning), a player can wager for more or less peg movements based on a hopeful outcome. Experienced fans may know when good players are coming up to bat and decide to risk their peg's movement.
Players are encouraged to be creative in their wagers.

—description from the designer

name: Dice Maze
description:
User summary
Dice Maze is a two-player maze game. You place and move your dice in a 7x7 square grid to force your opponent to be unable to move. The game is language free, although published in Japanese.

At beginning of the game, both players place their pawn in any vacant square of their choice.

In your turn, you do the following:
1-a) Place one of your dice from your reserve onto any vacant square, showing one pip on top, or
1-b) Rotate (tumble) one of your dice on the grid N times, where N equals to number of pips of it.
2) Then, move your pawn in the same manner as a Rook in Chess (orthogonally).

When you rotate a die, turn it 90 degrees on a bottom edge in one of four directions.
You may capture your opponent's die if your die finishes all rotations in the same square with the same pips on top as the opponent's die.

You win the game when you capture three of your opponent's dice, or when your oppont's pawn is unable to move.

Publisher's summary
サイコロパズルの要素がある迷路ゲームです。
サイコロを壁として使い、相手の駒を動かせなくする迷路ゲームです。
自分の番になったら、サイコロを置くか動かし、その後で自分の駒をルークの動きで動かします。
サイコロは上になっている目の数だけ転がり、上手く同じ目になったら相手のサイコロを取れます。
相手の駒を動かせなくするか相手のサイコロを3個取ったら勝ちです。

name: Enigma Maze
description:
User summary
A two player abstract game from Japan. In the game of Enigma Maze, you try to advance your pawn to the opposite edge of 15x15 square grid, while blocking the opponent's pawn by placing polyominoes. The designer intended Enigma maze to be a cross between the games Quoridor and Lonpos (a brand of logic puzzles). The gameplay is language free, although published in Japanese.

In your turn, you do the followings:
1) Choose an unused polyomino and place it on the grid. Do not overlap it with any other, and do not completely block your opponent's pawn off.
2) Move your pawn in the same manner as a Rook in Chess (orthogonally).

Publisher's summary
Quoridor×Ronpos
【コリドール】×【ロンポス】
コリドールのような迷路ゲームにロンポス的なパズル要素が加わったゲームです。
壁がロンポスの曲がったピースなので、迷路らしさが感じられます。
ルールは非常にシンプルです。
自分の番になったら、壁を置いてから自分の駒をルークの動きで移動させます。
相手のゴールへの道を完全シャットアウトするような壁の置き方はできません。
先に反対サイドに到達したら勝ちです。

name: KARAOKE POKER
description:
User summary
KARAOKE POKER is a Japanese singing game.

In the game KARAOKE POKER, you try to recall lyrics which use specific words.

There are five cards spread on the table, and each player is dealt five cards. Each card contains two or three words.

Players have 60 seconds to recall a song which contains as many words on the table or in their hand as possible.

Then players take turns singing a song they have recalled for 15 seconds. For each card in which a word is sung this way, that player scores one point.

This game stimulates the memory center, so it is effective in brain training and antidementia. It also gives whomever wants to sing a reason to sing!

The game is published in Japanese but the designer has put a sample of English cards online.

Publisher's summary
配られたカード5枚と場にあるカード5枚の中にある言葉を使った歌を思い出して歌うゲームです。
記憶中枢を刺激するので、脳トレだけではなく認知症対策効果があると思われます。
また、歌いたい人に歌う理由を与えられます。

name: Pony Pix
description:
There are 12 horse photograph cards to complete. Players throw the dice to collect parts of each image and aim to piece together as many horses as possible.

On their turn, a player rolls both dice. If doubles are rolled, the player gets another turn. To start a pony, a 1 must be rolled. Pieces must be collected in sequential order (pieces are labeled 1 thru 6) and multiple puzzles may be worked on simultaneously. A player may also sum the two dice to take a puzzle piece if it's the next one they need.

Players can also steal the #1 horse part from each other if they roll a 1 and no more are available from the center of the table. However, they must take it from the player with the most ponies and only of that pony hasn't been completed up to the fourth piece. When this happens, the player who had their piece stolen must return the remaining pieces of that pony to the center.

Play continues until the last pony is completed. The player with the most horses wins the game.

name: Rampaging Jotunn: Reverse Deck
description:
Rampaging Jotunn: Reverse Deck is an alternative to the deck of cards in the original game!

It has 74 cards that reverse all the movements and turns on the previous cards. For example, if the original card said 2 Turn two Facings Forward 2 Movement Points the Reverse Deck card says Forward 2 Movement Points Turn 2 Facings. This offers a fresh and challenging way to play Rampaging Jotunn!

The Reverse Deck also features the Rampage Card which allows the Jotunn to move on its own!

Note: Rampaging Jotunn is required to use these cards.
categories: Ancient, Card Game, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting, Medieval, Mythology
mechanics: Action Points, Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hand Management, Modular Board, Player Elimination

name: AESQ
description:
AESQ is a 4X board game that relies on deckbuilding mechanics. It is set in the Eastern Mediterranian during the Iron Age, in which all myths and believes of the time, like faeries, demons, witches and sorcerers, heroes and deities, are actual.

The game is for 1 to 5 players with 5 starting factions. Each player begins with a core deck that upgrades by acquiring unit and action cards, deploys armies and expands their territory by exploration and conquest.

name: Run Nibbles Run
description:
Run Nibbles Run is a fast pace reaction game for party, by flipping game cards, following tasks specified in cards , making funny faces, building blocks, sending nibbles back to home, or playing hide and seek, all must be done within one minute.

1. First put all the game components on table, starts from youngest player, initially clockwise.

2. Everyone shouts: Run Nibbles Run, and put the sandtimer upside down start the game round.

3. Flip over top card drom draw pile, complete task on each card, for task been done, you get the card.

4. After finish one card, rapidly flip over another card, try to collect more cards within one minute.

5. The player who gets most nuts on cards is the winner.

—description from the designer

name: The Hollow Earth
description:
The Hollow Earth is a tabletop skirmish game set in the Victorian era. With hints of Lovecraft the game sees gangs fighting over territory and attempting to take control of the trade routes established since the breach into the Hollow Earth.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Pick-up and Deliver, Player Elimination, Push Your Luck, Role Playing, Tile Placement, Variable Phase Order, Variable Player Powers

name: Oiligopoly
description:
Oiligopoly tries to parallel as much as possible the real world oil industry while at the same time trying to keep the game simple and interesting. For example, a player must find crude-oil, refine it into gasoline, and then sell the gasoline. This is done by landing on an oil well property to collect a round crude-oil chip, taking the round chip to a refinery property where it is exchanged for a square gasoline chip, and and taking the square chip to a gas station property where it is sold to the bank.
—description from the instruction manual

Oiligopoly uses Monopoly-style concepts to simulate the oil industry, while adding some unique play elements which help it work with the theme.
—user summary
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Pick-up and Deliver, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Simulation

name: Giant Giggly Winks
description:
A twist on Tiddlywinks. The 'board' is a vinyl mat on a grand scale. It shows flowers with petals. Players have a launcher each which is spring-loaded. The flip their counters on to the board. The first to get all their counters on to the flowers, wins.
The box illustrates a game in play.

—user summary

name: Get the Shinies
description:
Players take on the role of adventurers and race to gather mysterious creatures in this otherworldly safari.

The cards:
• Adventure cards provide step-by-step instructions to setup and play through each round.
• Shinies are the gemmed bugs that players try to capture during adventures.
• Catchies represent the items and methods used to capture shinies.
• Missions are the assignments given to players during the game to be completed for bounties. (Requirement varies.)
• Bounties award/ represent treasure, the currency used to determine the winner. (Reward amount varies.)

Setup:
• Players start by separating the cards into five draw stacks by type (adventures, shinies, catchies, missions, and bounties).
• Each player draws 5 catchies to form their hand.
• Each player draws 1 mission to complete.
That's it, you're ready to play!

Gameplay:
Get the shinies is broken down into a series of rounds known as "adventures".

• Before each round players replenish their hand of catchies, as necessary (up to the maximum of five).
• At the beginning of each round an adventure card is placed into the center of the play area to guide players through the setup and gameplay of each round.
• Players then take alternating turns matching their catchies with shinies to capture them as directed by the adventure card until the round is over.
• At the end of each round players check to see if they've captured enough shinies to complete their mission. If enough shinies have been captured the player: exchanges the required number of shinies for a bounty card, discards the completed mission along with the required shinies, and draws a new mission.

This process is repeated until 10 missions have been completed collectively, ending the game.

When the game ends players discard any remaining missions, shinies, or catchies they have then reveal their bounty cards and add up their values. The player with the highest treasure value wins the game!

You'll need to manage your hand of catchies wisely while consistently making the right plays to hinder your opponent and advance yourself to ensure victory in this unpredictable contest because it's not a game of chance!

-description from designer

name: Eleições 20XX
description:
Eleições 20XX is about a fictional election in a fictional place. There are voter cards on the table, which show one or two preferences. Players use whatever it takes to make sure that voters who'd never vote for them anyway won't participate in the election, while those who might, vote for the right thing.
The player who gets the most votes at election time wins.
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Take That, Variable Player Powers

name: Penny Assassin
description:
Penny Assassin is a dice chucking assassination game for 1-4 players.

Run across rooftops, hide from guards, look for the perfect shot, and then slay the targets. The enemy guards are constantly on the move, so the players must look for the opportune passage to strike.

In Penny Assassin, you start as a lowly member of a gang. As you travel about the town of Rorcester, you get stronger and more powerful. Missions that took multiple turns in the beginning can be accomplished in a flash, at the end. This leads to a mad dash to the finish. Only one can become The Most Awesome Assassin.

1-4 players get 3 actions each, per turn. Players can move unlimited spaces around the board, until they need to perform an action, such as hiding, climbing, or shooting. Events bring new missions and orders for the guards and coppers. Completing missions brings nickels. Nickels and pennies gained can be used to move closer towards victory, or for gaining more power and better tools of the trade. This brings the battle of risk versus reward, as players vie for the best strategy to take down the targets.

Different characters, skills, abilities, weapons, and setups give lots of options to take down the many targets.

Can you become the Most Awesome Assassin?

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Modular Board

name: Nerd Battles
description:
Nerd Battles is a card game for 2-4 players where nerds of all kinds fight for victory. Each nerd card has a base attack, defense, and IQ. Extra attack and defense cards can be added to a nerd in battle, where their IQ value is the amount of extra cards they can add. A nerd's attack and defense values can also be boosted by adding a confidence token. Defeat 4 nerds and you win!

Everyone starts the game with 2 nerd cards, 4 battle cards, and 4 random confidence tokens. At the start of a turn, draw 1 nerd card, or 2 battle cards. Then choose to pit your nerd against an opponents' to start a battle, or simply play an action card. If you start a nerd battle, choose the player you want to attack, and put your nerd into play. Add battle cards to your nerd to increase their attack defense, keeping the number of cards at or under their IQ value. At this time, a confidence token can also be added to the nerd. If the token matches the nerd, they get a permanent +2 to attack and defense. If it's unmatching, it's only a +1 to those values, and is discarded at the end of the battle.

Then, the opponent needs to put a nerd into play to defend the attack. If they can successfully block the attack by getting enough defense to equal or be greater than the attack, they not only don't lose, but they may be able to add enough attack cards to counter attack and defeat the attacking nerd. They are still limited by the nerds IQ, but can also add a confidence token. Either way, the losing nerd hides in the winners basement (an area under the play area) and gets turned sideways. After the battle, all battle cards are discarded, but any nerds that didn't lose stay in play, face up. Discard down to 7 battle cards, and it's the next player's turn. First player to get 4 nerds in their basement wins!

-description from designer

name: Hero Team Quest
description:
Hero Team Quest is a co-op game designed for young children. Very few board games that kids are exposed to emphasize cooperation and team success. With Hero Team Quest, all the players compete together and the outcome of victory or defeat is shared by all players. The goal is to defeat the wizard before time runs out (when the goblin gives the crystal of magic to him). The goblin moves 2 spaces on the board every round, closer to the end. Players must get to the end and defeat the wizard before he gets there.

Players first form a hero team of four characters and each may obtain a magic power at the magic school - each power is a weakness of one of the four bosses in the game. As they move across the board, they look to avoid losing a turn by stepping in mud. Players stop on the battle spaces to roll the dice to defeat the various bosses. Certain powers will make the chance of success better for some characters. If you should lose, you go to the cage where you must roll a 1 on your turn to pick the lock. Otherwise, other players may come to your rescue if they should defeat the boss OR they can decide to continue on the path if time is of the essence.

The game does offer some choices and teamwork/communication, but is ultimately a simple game designed for young kids that is easy to follow. From a complexity standpoint, it's a step up from games such as Candyland, Chutes and Ladders, Sorry, etc. - but in a genre that most kids enjoy.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Area Movement, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Variable Player Powers

name: Rush in the Forest: Three Little Pigs
description:
Rush in the forest: Three Little Pigs - is a family board game. All the components of the game are made from ecofriendly plywood. The game board and the rest of the elements are assembled as a constructor in the 3-d puzzle format. The glue is not required for the game assembling. Age for self-assembly of the components of the game is 14+. Age to participate with the game is 8+. Gameplay - throw a dice's, go your character (pig) on the playing board and collect resources for building a house. During the game, you may be hampered by a secondary character (Wolf) or accidentally dropped effect cards (which may both interfere and help you). The goal of the game is to assemble the house faster than the other players.

—description from the publisher
categories: Action / Dexterity, Animals, Children's Game, Dice, Educational, Industry / Manufacturing, Math, Number, Territory Building
mechanics: Acting, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Network and Route Building, Roll / Spin and Move, Simulation, Take That, Tile Placement

name: Indictment
description:
Politics is a terrible and scary race to be in. Everyone has scandals, big and small, that they wish wouldn't see the light of day. However, the press always seems to find them...

In Indictment, players are politicians who are working hard to bury their scandals before the press can find them. Each turn, players play either scandal cards or cover-up cards. A player then chooses which scandal to reveal, hoping the next, bigger scandal is just around the corner to occupy the press. If they can't play a same level (number) of scandal or higher, they have to pick up all the revealed scandals. If you play the same level (i.e. same number) of scandal as your opponent, they can stack and give you special bonus actions.

Eventually, once you've eliminated of all your hidden scandals, you can finally get to putting those nagging open scandals behind you, knowing you will not be the last one left in the press.

There are no winners in this game of politics, with only the last one left holding onto scandals being indicted and losing.
mechanics: Hand Management, Player Elimination, Set Collection

name: The Siege of Tyler City
description:
A 20 minute old west war game for 2 players

The outlaw David Glynn has been rolling across the west ransacking and looting every town he and his gang come across. Tyler City is next in his cross hairs. The folks of Tyler City know he’s coming and will not go down without a fight. Welcome to the deadly game of maneuvers, counter-maneuvers, and shootouts in the old west. Welcome to the Siege of Tyler City!

The Siege of Tyler City is a quick area control game where each player sets their sides’ actions for the round, then plays out those actions in order. At the end of a round, if one player has met one of their winning conditions, the game ends and that player is the winner.

—description from the publisher

name: Dragon Fortress
description:
In Dragon Fortress you will build an Estate that consists of various crops, farms, barns, mills etc. Also, you must protect these valuable estate assets from approaching dragons, who wish to burn these structures down. Protecting your estate is accomplished by building Fortress Tower structures. A careful balance of Estate and Fortress cards are needed to be victorious in Dragon Fortress. You must have the largest Estate and defeat the dragons!

On your turn you will draw a card and play a card from your hand to your Estate line. This line will build linearly from left to right. You may also draw from the gold supply to help you purchase valuable upgrades for your Estate cards. Drawing from the supply on your turn may introduce a dragon that will attack your estate. The dragon will enter your Estate on the front line and move through each card until it burns your crops or is defeated by your towers.

Victory points are scored for defeating dragons and building the most lucrative Estate. The player with the most victory points after the last dragon is defeated will win the game.

-description from designer
categories: Card Game, Fantasy, Medieval, Territory Building

name: Toxic Logic
description:
Welcome to the card-based party game for adults where you create bizarre and hilarious "IF/THEN" statements, which we call Toxic Logic. The game is easy to learn, portable, and tons of fun for 4 or more adults.

Here’s how it works:

Everyone is dealt 5 magenta “THEN” cards. The Dealer flips over a green “IF” card with the beginning of a conditional statement, like “IF you put a habanero pepper up your butt …” The other players each play one “THEN” card face down to the Dealer. The Dealer shuffles the “THEN” cards and then reads each “IF/THEN” combination:

“IF you put a habanero pepper up my butt …”
“THEN we're in for a big, sloppy surprise”
“IF you put a habanero pepper up my butt …”
“THEN these blueprints are all wrong”
“IF you put a habanero pepper up my butt …”
“THEN my new nickname is 'Sharty McFly'”
The Dealer picks a favorite “THEN” card and reads the winning IF/THEN combination out loud:

“IF you put a habanero pepper up my butt …”
“THEN my new nickname is 'Sharty McFly'”
The player of the winning “THEN” card gets a point. Everyone draws back up to 5 “THEN” cards, and the player to the left of the Dealer becomes the Dealer for the next round. You can keep your winning “THEN” cards to keep track of your own score. The first person to reach 5 points wins the game.

Toxic Logic is great for parties with 4 or more adults. You and your friends will have hours of laughs putting together “IF/THEN” statements which are absurd and so funny. Remember, “Toxic Logic” is not for kids! Some of the cards are filthy, and some of them are bizarre. While there is plenty of adult language and potty humor, rest assured that there is no racist or hate-based content. We want it to be fun for all adults! Put it all together, and you've got almost endless hilarity.

—description from the publisher
publishers: Shim and D'rothy Products Worldwide LLC

name: Captain Kangaroo's Colors Game
description:
This is an educational game for young children to help them learn their colours.

The game contains 36 learning cards, 6 wild cards, and 4 double-sided game boards. With these components, it's possible to play one of the five games in the box.

The five games are:
- Matching Pictures of the Same Color
- Matching Identical Pictures
- Matching Colors to Words
- "Fish" Game
- Reach for the Rainbow
categories: Children's Game, Educational, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Pile the Bones
description:
Pile the Bones is a dexterity game using pieces shaped like long bones. Each player places a bone on the playing surface to form a square base, then each player in turn places a new bone on the pile. The player who places the bone that collapses the pile scores one point for each bone in the pile. If a player plays the last bone without collapsing the pile that player reduces their score by 10 points. The player with the least points after an agreed number of rounds is the winner. Alternatively the players may play on individual piles of bones. In this case, there is no bonus for playing the last bone.

The game is packaged in a plastic barrel similar to Barrel of Monkeys.

name: Gallivant
description:
A world of knowledge... gallivanting the globe from your home or classroom. Expeditious expeditions of adventure in learning. A geography game played on an authentic and colorfully detailed world map. Fun and educational for teens and adults.

The game comes with four different categories of card (flags, general, capitals, countries). Players roll and move their pawn on a track. Each space on the track represents the color of card that must be answered. In order to move again on the same turn, players must answer their trivia cards correctly. For flag cards, players are shown a country flag with three possible answers on them. They must choose the correct answer to move again. General cards ask various questions related to physical or social geography. Country cards ask players to identify what country is being referred to on the map (each country of the world has been numbered on the board). Finally, players must identify the capital city of a specified country when they land on a country card.

To win the game, the player who lands on the finish space and answers one final trivia question correctly wins the game.

name: Team Zodiac
description:
A social deduction game for 3 to 4 players.

Welcome, team. Here is your mission for today. Your task is to liberate the captured base by sending in 12 agents. The good news is that if an agent's identity can be kept hidden, that agent can do the work of two normal agents. However, we believe the enemy may have sent an infiltrator who will try to sabotage our plan.

Team Zodiac may be played using standard playing cards or with the zodiac‐themed deck found in the files section. Players take turns playing an agent card either face up or face down. Face down cards count double. Some cards may also be used to accuse another player of being the infiltrator. The players win either by playing enough agent cards or by correctly accusing the infiltrator. The infiltrator, if there is one, wins by foiling the playing of agent cards without being detected.

This is an updated version of a game created for the April 2017 24 Hour Contest.

-description from designer
categories: Card Game, Print & Play, Spies/Secret Agents

name: Get Organized
description:
Get Organized is a mafia-based card and dice game. The goal is to accumulate 100 or more points by collecting “Industry Cards.” Each player begins with 1 of each industry card in play (Strip Clubs, Drug Trafficking, Waste Management, Money Laundering, Gambling Ring and Law Enforcement). Each turn begins with a “Collect” phase, where the player takes $200 from the “stash.” Then there is a “Purchase” phase, where they player may choose to purchase more industry cards (kept in their hand for now, but not in play) or bullets to attack with. Next is the “Attack” phase, where the player can choose to roll dice to “shoot the bullets” at another player’s industry cards. If a 4+ is rolled, the player takes that card and adds it to his/her industry cards in play. Finally, there is the “Build” phase, which is when a player may play one industry card that was purchased earlier.

The first player to accumulate 3 of any one industry card in play, “owns” that industry and gains the benefits of it (for example, the person who owns the Gambling Ring gets to roll a die during his/her collect phase and collects $100 X the number they roll, in addition to the $200 they already collect). Every time an industry is taken over, the player who now owns it gets to pull a “Good Earner” card, which can be saved and used at any time (for example, there is a bullet proof vest, which makes bullets only hit on 5’s and 6’s for one attack phase).

After each round, the player with the most industry cards in play (not counting the ones purchased but not played yet) is the “Rat.” They must pull a rat card, which almost always has a negative action that must be taken. The Rat goes first in the next round, which isn’t always a good thing.

Each industry card in play is worth 5 points, but once the player owns the industry, all the cards within that industry are worth 10 points for that player. The game ends when there are one or more players over 100 points at the end of the round (the one with the most points wins). If someone gets over 100 points in the middle of a round, others can attack that player to reduce their points to less than 100.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Variable Player Powers

name: III Caesars: Roman Civil War of AD 69
description:
Rome had been a Republic with Senators for about 500 years. Then came the line of emperors: Julius, Augustus, Tiberius, Calligula, Claudius, and then the sixth evil Emperor Nero. After the beast Nero committed suicide in AD 68 after an attempt to prove he was God incarnate, it appeared the Roman Empire had received a fatal wound to its head (leadership) which could not be healed. Three Caesars: The Roman Civil War of AD 69 re-creates this struggle. Galba, Ortho, and Vitellius engaged in a war where Romans fought against their fellow Romans to see who would become the next emperor of Rome.
Historically, none of them succeeded, either militarily or politically. Can you succeed where they failed? If not, General Vespasian is on his way to Rome to proclaim himself emperor, and begin the Flavian Dynasty.

III Caesars is a card driven game wherein the first player to get to Rome, conquer it, and acquire 10 political points wins immedaitely.

—description from the publisher

name: Assassin's Creed: Arena – Hookblade Promo Card
description: Pre-order bonus of a Hookblade promo card from the Cryptozoic Store.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Video Game Theme

name: Scoria
description:
Scoria is a deck building game for 1-2 players. In Scoria players adventure within a cavern beneath an erupting volcano. The players seek the idols that hold the power of the ancients- if awoken, balance can be restored to the island. The player who has gathered the most power by invoking the ancients will win.
The players start with a basic deck of spell cards - these cards are used to accumulate more powerful spell cards or to win the favor of an idol. Each idol has a requirement for how much spirit the player must have in their hand - spirit comes in 6 different types - and each spell card could contain a variety as well. In addition to invoking the idols, the spells a player accumulates through drafting can be used to negatively effect their opponent, or positivity effect themselves. Once a player has obtained the favor of three idols the game ends - and players total their power; each idol has an associated power value. The player with the most power wins.

name: The Road Crew
description:
Take on the role of a roadie, and help your band become the most popular act at the biggest music festival of the year!

'Juice' their songs, sort out event issues and sabotage other bands to GAIN the most fans by the end of your set list!

In this fun, fast paced, take that game, each player tries to assist their band in gaining as many fans as possible during their 12 song set list.

Each song can create new fans providing the roadie has the skills (in the shape of 4 unique tokens) to ‘juice’ their band’s songs. The more tokens used, the more fans the players can chuck into the moshpit.

However, they may need to keep some energy in reserve as Every festival has it’s share of unfortunate events, and this one is no exception.

Throw into the mix the other roadies trying to sabotage your stage and gear, you know you’ve got your hands full trying to be the best band on the biggest stage!

name: Dumpster Dealers
description:
Persuade your friends to buy absurd products in this hilarious NSFW party game.

We believe great party games should encourage you to express your own sense of humor, not just rely on each card to be a pre-written punchline. That's why we created Dumpster Dealers.

Dumpster Dealers is a hilarious game of creative persuasion.
Here's how it works:
1. Choose a Customer
One person draws a Dumpster Dollar and chooses a role to adopt from either side of the card. They will be determining the winner of the round

2. Create Products
Everyone else quickly combines two of their Dumpster Cards into something the Customer might want.

3. Pitch Your Products
Each player attempts to persuade the Customer why their ridiculous card combination is best. Hilarity ensues.

4. The customer awards the Dumpster Dollar to their favorite product, ending the round. The winnner gets to be the customer for the next round.

That's the main sequence of gameplay, not including the addition of bonus rounds, extra house rules, or drinking game rules.

—description from the designer
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Humor, Mature / Adult, Party Game
mechanics: Acting, Cooperative Game, Role Playing, Storytelling, Voting

name: Get Elected
description:
Get Elected is a card game for 3 to 8 players (ages 16 and up) where you have your presidential candidate attend funny campaign events, hold silly fundraisers to earn money and popularity, make outrageous promises, play scandals on your opponents (because it's always fun to trip up the other candidates), avoid the scandals yourself by spinning the news, participate in some debates, and win states. Once your candidate has earned the electoral points (states) needed to win, then you win.

It's easy to learn, hilarious to play, fast-paced, more fun than the actual elections, and without long-term consequences!

Here's how you actually play the game:
After rolling the dice to see who goes first, in turn order everyone selects a Candidate. Each Candidate comes with its own unique special ability. Everyone gets starting money, 3 Event cards, and 3 Situation cards. Players (in turn order) draw a State Card to see which they will be competing for that turn.
Your Candidate will collect a campaign salary for the turn.
You will then draw an Event card and a Situation card from the decks. Now you can play as many Event and Situation cards from your hand as you want: some are useful playing on yourself, others are fun to use to mess with the other Candidates. Your goal here is to earn money and popularity points. The more you have, the better the chance to win the State at the end of your turn. After all of the card play, everyone competes for the State. To win the State (and its electoral points), you roll the die, add in your popularity tokens to the roll, and subtract any negative points from Scandal cards that other players may have dropped on you. The player with the highest net total wins that State. Game play proceeds like this until one Candidate has enough electoral points to win the game. (The number of points needed to win is determined by how many players are in the game.)

It's straightforward and easy to play - a typical game of 4-5 players taking about an hour. This game never bogs down, doesn't require political knowledge, does not take any political stances, and is not designed as an educational game about politics. This is a fun little game about winning by accumulating points and messing with your opponents to prevent them from doing the same!

-description from designer
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Take That, Variable Player Powers

name: Get Real
description:
A board game with overtones of real life, but a lot more fun than the real thing! You can play 3 to 8 players (ages 16 and up), starting off with a decision of whether to get to work or go get educated (sound familiar?). But from there this game diverges from humdrum life, as you move your token along the board you can get to do and experience things that maybe you only wish you could do, or in some cases - wish that you could avoid!

How the game plays:
Once everyone has their starting money and figured out who goes first, each player will decide whether you want to obtain an Occupation that requires a degree or one that does not. Both sets are unique. You will start your turn by drawing a Redefine card. Then you will use your Occupation Special ability (if applicable) if you want. The Occupation abilities are funny and unique to each job. You'll roll the die to see how many spaces to move your token on the game board. (Yes, this game does feature that old-school notion of rolling dice for movement.)
Then you and other players can start using Redefine cards on yourself or on each other. These "wild cards" can have a fun and unexpected effect on the game - either helping yourself, helping others, hindering others, or downright messing with the other players in funny ways. You will move your token forward on the game board, following the instructions on the space you land on. Usually this means you draw a card from a specific deck and follow its instructions. Then there can be another round where you and other players can use Redefine cards again.
And that’s about it – this is where your turn will normally end, and on it goes until you reach the Get Done space, cash out, and wait to see who has the most money (cash, properties, other assets). If you have kids, you can cash them in for money at the end - because children can have value!

Whoever has the most money at the end, wins!

The typical game of 5-6 players will take about 2 hours to complete. But it will be a very hilarious two hours! This game is a kick to play, fun for most age groups, and will definitely satisfy the need to experience life the way you always wished it could be!

-description from designer
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Take That, Variable Player Powers

name: Expect!
description:
Expect!, previously known as Experience:Streetwar or XPSW, is a surprisingly swift, match-n-tactics card game for 2-4 players.
Players build color groups from their cards on a 5x5 grid, to score as many points as possible, and mix in useful effects to gain more options.
Card positioning and the board itself plays a key role in the gameplay - the game quickly changes from easy score-grinding to fight over last positions, and back.
The finish line is set to 100 points, whoever finds the quickest way to beat it, gains control over the grid :)
Expect! the unexpected. Easy to learn, interesting to discover, challenging to master, coated in nice comic-based design and tested on humans.
mechanics: Hand Management, Pattern Building, Set Collection

name: Murder à la carte: The Spice of Death
description:
From the box:

Enjoy a little murder with your dinner?...
Everyone's a suspect when murder is on the menu. And with Murder à la Carte you have everything you need to serve up the perfect murder dinner party. First the invites, you choose which of your friends play which devious suspect and invite them to come along as that character. Then the shopping list, menu suggestions and recipes. Plus of course... a really tasty murder to solve. We guarantee that it will be drop dead fun, and that by the end of the evening one (or more) of the suspects, your 'friends', will be caught out as the murderer!!

The year is 1930, the place Northern India. It is becoming increasingly clear that the days of the British Raj are numbered. There are tensions between the English and the Indians and between the Hindus and Muslims. You are invited to 'Dunruttin' the residence of Colonel and Mrs Hurley-Burley. One of the guests Lt Chance fails to arrive. he has been murdered. Those present at the dinner party including the murderer:
Colonel Hurley-Burley VC, British army officer and loyal soldier of the empire.
Mrs Camilla Hurley-Burley, his younger, and glamorous, wife.
Elizabeth Hurley-Burley, their 21 year old strong willed daughter.
Jasvinda Loo, a Hindu nationalist educated in England with Elizabeth.
Imran Khant, a playboy, fond of women, sport and gambling.
Fritz Metz, a young South African businessman.
Mata Harem, a retired Turkish Spy.
Sage Aloo, a Hindu guru, an old rogue who enjoys life.

Contents:
Party planner with game rules, recipes, music and decorating tips.
Character booklets, including their roles, background information and a few tasty secrets.
Place cards for each character.
Party invitations and envelopes for each character.
Six secret clues.
Cassette tape with an introduction, scene setter, summary of events and solution to the crime.

name: The Melt
description:
Since the days of The Melt back in the early 2100s, people feared the horrors of the ocean. Most wouldn't dare to even approach it. A small group of dreamers created "Remember the Sea", an optimistic and nostalgic bunch who were drawn to, one day, commune with the sea again. You were one such visionary spirit.

On January 31, 2307, Remember the Sea finally turned vision into reality with the launching of Moonbeam. A floating city constructed from an ancient ship that used to be called an aircraft carrier, Moonbeam took the members of Remember the Sea out into the ocean. Finally, after centuries of waiting, you and your fellow explorers took your first anxious steps out into the great unknown. These are your stories of discovery, wonder, and adventure. Here's hoping you return alive from The Melt...

name: サムライソウルフード (Samurai Soul Food)
description:
User summary
Charge up your Samurai Soul by satisfying the Lord with your art of cuisine!

Who will win the Go-Zen-Battle? Sharpen your blade and get ready for the fight!

サムライソウルフード (Samurai Soul Food) is a card game with a theme of cooking. The Lord orders players to cook three dishes as a team.

Each round, players are ordered to cook one dish of meal as a team. Each player places one ingredient card face-down, then all the cards are revealed. The cooking is successful if conditions written in the order card are met. Each player scores Samurai Soul depending on the cards played.

The game ends after three successful rounds, in which case highest scorer wins the game; or after two unsuccessful rounds, in which case the Lord orders harakiri to all players, resulting no winner.

Publisher's summary
トノサマの御題に沿った料理を作り、サムライソウルを貯めよ！
“御膳死合”の勝者は……いざ尋常に、空前御膳を作るべし。

御膳死合で御題に沿った料理を3回完成させ、「サムライソウル」の合計が一番多かったプレイヤーが勝者となります。

name: A True Scotsman!
description:
A True Scotsman! is a small card game that combines deduction with clever card-play that aims to create a fun and engaging gaming experience for two players in 5-15 minutes.

Throughout the game players must expose the Traitor in their enemy's ranks. As insults fly from either side of the battlefield, certain members of each clan are compelled to lift their kilts in contempt! However, will this act of defiance reveal a true Scotsman or uncover an Englishman - and the spy amidst their ranks...?

On their turn, players will play cards representing the troops and events on the battlefield, trying to expose the Traitor hidden in their enemy's ranks. However, other events represent the Traitor's ability to remain hidden – but as soon as his luck runs out, he is exposed as an Englishman and his clan’s claim to the throne is lost. This player’s opponent wins the game.

-description from designer
categories: Card Game, Deduction, Medieval, Print & Play

name: Ball Busters: Football
description:
from the back of the box: "The Ultimate Playbook of Puzzlers. Whether you're a serious football fan or a casual Sunday warrior, Ball Busters will challenge and amuse the competitor in you with brainteasers and curious questions featuring football stats and stars of yesteryear and today.

Test your knowledge of football with your family and friends and see how much you really know when it comes to football then and now.

Score a touchdown every time you play."

This is a trivia card game with a football theme. The deck of question cards is passed around the table with each player answering a question until there is an incorrect response. The deck then moves to the right with another player attempting to provide the answers. The first contestant to get three correct answers in a row is declared the winner.

name: Wir fahren Dampfschiff
description: The players travel with their steamboats on the Elbe from Mühlberg to Leitmeritz. Movement is determined by a die. The first player to reach space 40 wins the game.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Spinnefix
description: The player with the fly starts at the center of the web and tries to get to one of the 6 exit points to win the game. The other player starts with 5 spiders on 5 of the 6 exit points. The spiders win the game if they manage to force the fly back to the center space. Each player moves one space per turn.

name: Attacco
description:
The goal of the game is to occupy the enemy's stronghold (red or green square) At the beginning of the game, the pawns are placed on the small dots of their color. Movement is 1 space in any direction (straight or diagonal). Jumping over other pawns to an empty space behind them is also possible. Jumped over enemy pawns are eliminated from the game. The brown spaces may not be entered.
The doted spaces outside of the triangle around the stronghold are forts. Pawns in the fort may not be jumped over. If a player enters the enemy stronghold with a pawn, he wins the game.

name: RenFest!
description:
Roam through the Queen’s Garden, the Fool’s Court, and the other groves of the greatest Renaissance Festival in the land. Be the first to visit the Taverns, Stages, Crafts, and other delights. Grab a Turkey Leg for an energy boost, purchase a Royal Pass to cut in line, or shop for the finest Souvenirs of your trip to the past. Claim the weekend’s best experiences and be crowned Ruler of RenFest!

Hex tiles build out a board of activities in seven types, such as Shoppes and Taverns. Each set of seven tiles forms a Grove, and the board contains one grove per player (3 to 6.) Parking spots line the edge of the groves, or a player can choose to save money by parking remotely and taking an extra turn to reach the activities.

Turns move quickly as the clock advances through the three nine-hour days of a long weekend at the RenFest. The starting player advances a clock dial piece one hour before each round.

The first player to reach each event has the option to claim the spot for the day. At the end of each day, the player with the most activities claimed in each grove scores points. Each player has only six Stamina per day, representing the energy needed to experience an activity. Stamina can also be used to run up to 3 steps to get ahead of other players.

At the end of the game, players score scaled points for collecting sets of the same activity type from multiple groves.

A limited supply of money must last the whole weekend. Shoppe tiles sell Souvenir cards with bonus points and special abilities. Food tiles allow purchase of extra Stamina for the day.

At the Royal Court space, players can buy Royal Pass cards that allow claiming an event that has already been claimed.

A player can choose to use their turn to leave early, making them starting player for the next day. Turn order is the final tie breaker.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Set Collection, Turn Order: Time Track

name: Irrgarten
description:
The players start with one pawn each at the edges of the game board. Movement is determined with a die. The first player to reach the center space wins the game.

The game was produced in Belgium.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Aschenbrödel
description: The players start at the kitchen and try to reach the castle in the center of the game board. Movement is determined by a spinning top. On the spin of a 4, the player draws a heart and follows the instructions printed on it. On some spaces, events hinder or benefit the player. The first player at the castle wins the game.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Mensch, tipp richtig!
description:
The players use their betting tokens to bet on the results of all four teams (S=Sieg/win, N=Niederlage/loss, X=Unentschieden/draw).

Then the players move their footballs from space A to one of the three destination spaces (S, N, X). Movement is determined by a die. On the roll of a 6 between space A and the black space, the ball has to go back to space A. If the 6 is rolled after the black space or if the ball reaches space B, it goes back to the black space.

When all 4 teams have reached a destination space, the winnings are determined according to the occupied destination space of each team and the submitted bets of the players.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move
publishers: Esslinger Verlag J. F. Schreiber GmbH

name: Bragging Rights
description:
Bragging Rights is a game of competitive bullshitting. Everyone plays as the world's incompetent criminal underbelly, all trying to gain street cred for a crime none of you committed.

Players can play as a set character with traits or a new one made up on the spot. The players draw evidence cards, create a play pile for the game and keep a hand of three pieces of evidence they can swap in. Every game has one specific crime, from stealing the Mona Lisa from the Louvre, to Replacing church bells with maracas.

Each round a piece of evidence is turned over and every player has to construct a unique story of how they left that at the crime scene. As the rounds go on more evidence must be woven into your stories trying to keep them as consistent as possible. But watch out, if you mess up and your story stops making sense other players can wager their street cred to call you out on it. You’ll need to convince everyone at the table that you’re making sense to not lose face (and points).

At the end of the game a Story Winner is chosen and players count up their street cred. Whoever has the most cred earns bragging rights for this crime.

-description from designer
mechanics: Acting, Betting and Bluffing, Memory, Role Playing, Storytelling, Voting

name: Center Stage
description:
The theater in your small town is having a hard time getting people to come in to see its plays. They need your help coming up with ideas for plays that will bring lots of customers in. There’s a catch, though! They have a very limited budget, so you’ll need to work with the sets, characters, and props that the theater already has. And you'll also have to deal with the directors - some of them have their own agenda. Come in and pitch your story – be creative and you’ll win the prize role of Chief Theater Writer among your competitors!

Center Stage is a storytelling card-based game. Players take cards from each of three decks: sets, props, and characters. They must then develop a quick story including each of these random elements. One player each round serves as the director. He/She takes a card indicating a direction or goal for the winning story - that only the director knows. Players tell their stories, and the director chooses the best one. The winning storyteller receives $1, which may be used as a victory point, or to choose a different card when telling a story. The first player to 5 points wins.

—description from the publisher

name: Maipú 1818
description: The game simulates the battle of Maipú which marked the end of Spanish colonial rule of Chile. Each player picks an officer card at the beginning of the game which has certain unique characteristics, like a fighting bonus in certain types of battle. They command different units with numerical values for attack, damage, movement, range, defense and resistance. Battles are decided by rolling 2d6.

name: Rock Paper Monsters
description:
[Overview]
Rock Paper Monsters is a turn-based card game that follows the core mechanics of Rock Paper Scissors, with an added element of scoring points based off of the card value. Every card has a cartoon illustrated monster, with some having trigger abilities that occur at various points in the game.

Players take turns playing Monster or Bonus cards to both destroy opponent’s cards and score the most points. Each Monster type has a strength and weakness against another type. Bonus cards can be played instead of a Monster card, providing unique advantages. The player with the highest score after all cards are played wins a Monster Bite. Cards are then reshuffled and the next round begins. The first player to 10 Monster Bites wins.

[Gameplay]
Beginning Phase:
Each player draws 6 cards. Then, each player takes 3 cards off the Draw pile and places then face down in a row across from each other. When ready, flip over each card and determine the winning Monster. Monster cards battle directly across from each other.

Play Phase:
At the start of a player’s turn, they may choose to discard 1 card in hand and draw 1 card from the Draw pile.

Next, the player plays 1 card immediately to the left or to the right of one of their cards in play. If they have no cards in play, they must play a card across from one of their opponent’s cards. When playing a Monster Card, if their opponent has a Monster Card directly across from their Monster Card, they begin the [Battle]. When playing a Bonus Card, no battle occurs.

This completes their turn and it is now their opponent’s turn to play. Continue alternating turns until all cards in hand are played.

name: Monkey Bash
description:
The bananas are almost gone, this is no time to monkey around!

Monkey Bash is a fast paced, tactical battle card game with tons of monkey shenanigans. Every card does something: from simple effects, to game turning if played right. Card position and movement matters as much as the cards themselves. Strategy and wits will play a big role in your victory, but you can still pull off even the most harebrained schemes with a bit of luck (or enough cheater monkeys).

Be the first player to collect 20 bananas, then hold them for 2 rounds. But watch out, the other monkeys may try to steal them. So, upgrade your Base with a Fort, or maybe a Cannon!
categories: Animals, Card Game, Environmental, Fighting, Territory Building
mechanics: Area Movement, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling, Take That

name: Battle of the River Plate: A Battle Game Book
description:
Battleship Captain is a "miniatures" game system with scenarios played on the tabletop or floor, using the rules and ship counters provided. The game emphasizes playability, as players maneuver their ships and try and defeat the enemy fleet.

This Battlegame Book is a 42-page book containing a WW2 tactical naval game for 2 players, using simplified Battleship Captain system, with full rules, River Plate, Denmark Strait, Mers-El-Kebir scenarios, 20 rated warships (BB, BC, CA, CL) at 1/4500 scale. Updates and expands the original 2011 game.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Nautical, Wargame, World War II

name: Astrodyssée
description:
The goal of the game is to conquer a maximum number of planets from the solar system.

Each player is to take turns to a planet. A player can explore more than one planet per trip. A planet can be explored by several players. A player marks his or her arrival on a plate with a pawn under. A player should always have 3 cards in his or her hand. Each turn a player chooses a card, places it face up next to the board, and performs the action of the card. Upon returning to Earth, a player awaits the next turn to start a new trip.

name: Vamos  a la playa!
description:
The goal of the game is to complete his sandcastle first or finish with the most decorations.

Each player selects a base, puts it on the table and then places alongside it the eight pieces of the sandcastle of the corresponding colour.

Each turn involves three actions:
