Drink spaces require pulling a drink card from a pile in the center of the gameboard and simply taking that number of drinks before throwing the card in a discard pile to be shuffled and placed back in the center when there are no more drink cards to draw.

Fight spaces require the player to draw a fight card from the pile in the center of the board. These unique characters all have a power rating from 1 to 6. The player then has to roll a six sided die against the power of the fight card. If they win they keep the card and can use it once against their opponents to knock them back on the gameboard a number of spaces equal to the power of the card. If they lose they drink the difference of their roll and the power of the fight card as well as move back that many spaces on the gameboard.

The third type of spaces are home and the bar themselves. These are safe spaces where no fighting can occur. Otherwise no two players can occupy the same space on the board and will have to fight each other (by each rolling dice) to see who stays on the space and who gets bumped back the difference of the two rolls on the gameboard.

—description from the designer

name: Vojo
description:
In the most needy Africa, nothing is easy for the most isolated villages. Vojo is a card game of adventure and strategy in which you must build your best route overcoming difficulties and crossing the different territories to achieve your goal, bring the water to those who need it most. Overcoming earthquakes or dodging thieving monkeys are just some of the tests you will have to pass in your adventure.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Hand Management, Network and Route Building

name: Adventures of a Classroom Exorcist!
description:
A solitaire Tarot card game of making connections and finding demons.

In this game you take on the role of a teenage exorcist. You had transferred to this school when you learned of a demon possessing one of the students. As you arrive, you can sense the demon within but cannot pinpoint the exact student.

During the following schoolyear it’s your job to make as many allies as you can, identify your foe and drive out the demon. But remember, the demon will be turning your classmates against you too.

'—description from the introduction

The game is provided as a print-and-play PDF document (25 pages). Several pages of the document are needed for reference during play (even for experienced players). Play requires a Tarot deck of cards, though a mapping table can be used to play with a standard pack of French playing cards. Play involves card distribution into several distinct, named piles (Friend, Classmate, Rival, and Discard). When play begins, most cards are placed in the Classmate pile representing students. The goal of play is to transfer cards from the Classmate pile to the Friend pile. The "demon" works against you, moving cards from the Classmate pile to the Rival pile.

Play proceeds in three phases. During the first phase the identity of the "demon" is unknown. During the second phase the identity of the "demon" is known. The third phase is the final period of the game when the player and the "demon" have the "final battle" - the outcome of which determines if the solitaire player wins or loses the game.

The first two phases essentially are discovery and building phases, with the player attempting to gather as many resources as possible (thus denying them to the "demon") - this is represented by the distribution of cards into the Friends or Rivals piles. The third phase determines victory in the game - the player wins, or the "demon" wins (thus, the player loses).

Throughout the game, the principle action involves card manipulation to influence a basic card vs. card flip where the winner, by default, is determined by suit and rank (court cards always beat number cards, etc.). Too, each court card is identified as a specific "student" in the school, and each student has variable power. For example, "The Sun" equates to student "Hiroko Harunobu" - who has specified powers over "The Moon". Unsurprisingly, "The Moon" equates to Hiroko's younger twin, "Horie Harunobu" - who has specified powers over "The Sun".

Because the cards are randomly distributed by shuffling, replay will always be unpredictable. While essentially a solitaire card game at heart, the extended game concept and especially the variable card effects create quite a nuanced game that would lend itself well to an immersive experience.

—user summary
mechanics: Hand Management, Trick-taking, Variable Player Powers

name: Star Thieves
description:
Star Thieves is a fast-paced, tactical action game where the shape of the game board and circumstances are constantly changing until the end.

Players aim to find a route into the center of the space station by revealing the path one step at a time. First one there will find and capture the coveted Crystal Star, once used to power the ancient space station. With the priceless loot in his possession, he must make his way to one of the remaining escape pods while all others try to stop him by any means necessary.

Hindering and making other player’s progression more difficult is done by activating various faults and traps, summoning aliens residing inside the space station, manipulating the shape of the broken-down structures, using any found weaponry to shoot or defeating the opponent in a duel. Beware, the Star Thief with the Crystal Star in his possession will immediately be the target of all other competitors...

The winner is the player who can make his way into the escape pod carrying the Crystal Star, or by being the last remaining Star Thief on the space station!

—description from the publisher

name: Kill It with Fire
description:
Kill It with Fire is a 2 - 4 player worker placement game, where players are evil overlords attempting to corrupt a city. Players start with 2 Minion workers and need to build a lair so they may complete evil schemes, gain more minions, build laboratories and enhance their minions, gain Evil and complete Grand Schemes. The player who has the most Evil when the city’s Temple is corrupted wins. Beware, as the player’s minions gain Evil throughout the course of the game their minions will start to gain Free Will and try to attack the players every time they are used. It’s up to the players to collect Vials of Dragonfire so that when the time feels right they can kill their minion with fire and gain double the amount of evil.

—description from the designer

name: Market Day
description:
Free game published in the June 2018 (GTM #220) issue of Game Trade Magazine.

The game utilizes the Pairs game system and is designed with the Commonwealth Deck, though it can be played with any Pairs deck.

Background: Market Day is a game about bringing your goods to market! Each hand a is series of rounds in which some merchants will prosper, and some will struggle.

Equipment: A Pairs deck and a way to keep score.

Setup: To start the hand, shuffle the deck and deal six cards to each player. Note the alternate rules for 2-3 players, below.

Sequence of Play: On each round, every player will play one card face up, going in turn to the left. On the first round, play begins on the dealer’s left. On later rounds, play begins with the player who took the most points on the previous round. If this is tied, which is rare, then the same person leads the next round.

Generally, each card played in the round is worth its face value in points. However, if more than one card of the same rank are played, then the earlier ones are “spoiled” and only the last one scores. For example, if three 8’s are played, only the last 8 can score.

There are also five special cards, described below, which do not behave by these basic rules.

Rules for 2-3 Players:
Players start with ten cards. Each player will play two cards on each round, so play proceeds twice around the table. Be sure to remember which cards were played in what order.

Special Cards:

Each of the following cards breaks the basic rules in its own way.

1: Tinker. At the end of the round, this card may trade places with any other card.

2: Knight. Before scoring, this card kills (discards) the highest scoring card. Knights cannot kill cards of rank 3 and lower. Playing a second Knight does not spoil the first, and they can each kill a card.

3: Royal. This card cannot be traded, killed, or spoiled. When you play a 3, you will always score it.

7: Rain. If only one Rain card is played, it spoils everything except Royals, including 1’s and 2’s. (The player who played the Rain does score the Rain card.) However, if more than one Rain card are played, treat them as ordinary 7’s.

9: Bandit. The first bandit, not the last, is the card that scores. Bandits played after the first one are spoiled.

The round ends after all players have played one card.
Before scoring, first remove any cards that are spoiled, and then check the other cards in the following order:
Royals, then Rain, Knights, and Tinker.

The hand is over when all cards have been played. A full game is six hands, or one hand for each player, whichever is greater.

name: Captain's Orders
description:
Free game published in the August 2018 (GTM #222) issue of Game Trade Magazine.

The game utilizes the Pairs game system and is designed with the Pirate Deck, though it can be played with any Pairs deck.

Story: You are mutinous pirates trying to gather a crew and overthrow the Captain. But the Captain and his allies hide among you, and they aim to foil your plans!

Captain’s Orders is a game of bluffing and deduction.

You Need: A Pairs deck and a way to keep score.

Definitions: The Captain is a secret player, the person holding the lowest ranked card. The identity of Captain can change whenever cards are played and passed. Sometimes there will be a tie for lowest card, so there may be more than one Captain.

All non-Captain players are Mutineers. Mutineers can win the round either by discovering the Captain, or by accumulating the most points in their hands. (Cards are worth their face value in points.) The Captain can win only by running out of cards.

Each Round: To begin the round, shuffle the deck and deal a hand of six cards to each player. Play begins on the dealer’s left and proceeds clockwise. Pass the deal to the left after each round.

On Your Turn: Your options are different depending on whether there is an Order on the table.

NO ORDER: If there is no Order on the table, you must do one of the following: play an Order, pass a card, ask for a card, or discover the Captain.

Play an Order: Play a card face up in the middle of the table. This card becomes an Order and you are its owner.

Pass a Card: Pass a card from your hand to another player, face down. That player must then discard one card face down.

Ask for a Card: Ask another player to pass you a card from their hand, face down. Then you must discard one card face down.

Discover the Captain: If you think you know who the Captain is, you can accuse that player. This ends the round, and all players must immediately reveal their hands to find the true identity of the Captain(s).

If you are a Mutineer, and you correctly identify the Captain, you win the round. Otherwise, you can’t win, and the other Mutineer with the most points wins the round.

STANDING ORDER: When an Order is on the table, your options are different. You must either follow or belay the Order, or discover the Captain as described above.

Exception: You do not respond to your own Order. If an Order has traveled all the way around the table, its owner simply discards it, and the turn passes to the left.

Follow the Order: Pass a card face down to the owner of the Order. The rank of the card you pass must be equal to or higher than the rank of the Order. (Note: there is no discard after this type of card pass.)

Belay the Order: Play a new Order of a lower rank than the current Order. The old Order is discarded, and the new one belongs to you.

Ending the Round: The round ends when any player runs out of cards, or tries to discover the Captain.

Running out of Cards: Whenever you empty your hand, either by passing a card or by playing an Order, you may reveal that card and declare that you are the Captain. This ends the round, and if you’re right, you win. If you were passing that card away, and you are not the Captain, then the card passes into that player’s hand for scoring.

Ties for Captain: If more than one player holds the lowest card, then either of them can win by running out of cards, and Mutineers can win by accusing either of them. However, one Captain can’t win by identifying another one.

Ties for Points: If two or more Mutineers win with the same score, they each score a win for the round .

Winning: The first player to win three rounds wins the game.

name: KHG: Korrupte haben Geld – Quiz
description:
Who said that? A satirical quotes quiz against corruption.
A humorous foray through the Austrian corruption story with over 100 quotes from politics, finance and business.

—description from the publisher (translated)

In German: Wer hat’s gesagt? Das satirische Zitate-Quiz gegen Korruption. Ein humorvoller Streifzug durch die österreichische Korruptionsgeschichte mit über 100 Zitaten aus Politik, Finanz und Wirtschaft.

—description from the publisher (German)

name: Gun In A Knife Fight
description:
A card game of backstabbing your friends. Created by Summer Igloo Games, Gun In A Knife Fight is a game where players take turns drawing cards and either playing attack cards on each other or playing action cards to mess with another player’s plans. Everything ends when someone draws the gun card at which point scores are added up. The player with the highest score wins the fight. The game can be played with 2-10 players allowing you to backstab even more friends.

—description from the publisher

name: Enjambre Tácticas
description:
Enjambre Tácticas ("Swarm Tactics") is a fun and fast game for 2 to 6 players. Each player commands a swarm of bees in an attempt to conquer the honeycomb and capture the enemy bees.

Very easy to learn: The rules can be explained in under 2 minutes and the first game should not last more than 30 minutes.
Fast: Each game lasts between 15 and 20 minutes.
Challenging: You must devise your own strategy, trying to outwit the other players. The initial deployment of your bees is crucial and you need to adapt quickly to the movement of the enemy bees. And don’t forget where you put your most valuable bees!
Fun: You don’t know how powerful is an enemy bee until you are about to attack it! Or do you? Can you use your explorer bee to spy some of your enemies? Are you willing to risk a weak bee to lure your opponents into a trap? Or are you going with your most powerful bees in an all-out attack? And… what are they going to do?


Enjambre Tácticas is an exciting party game with all the elements to become a classic. The short game length engages the players to play again, trying different strategies in order to achieve victory… or vengeance!

—description from the designer

name: Language
description: Мова ("Language") is an entertaining and developing project. During the game you will fight for the title of linguist of the Belarusian language. To win, in addition to knowledge of the language, you will need ingenuity, speed and attentiveness. The game will be interesting, as those who use the Belarusian language constantly, and those who have just started to learn it, and five different types of rules give the game a unique, versatile, and high level of replayability.

name: Hexstars Card Game
description:
A hexagon shaped card game where players build upon each others' cards by matching edges by color and ideally by symbol too. When a player lays down a matching symbol they win a "space gem" or the right to steal a gem from an opponent. Win by ending with the most gems.
Also has rules for cooperative gameplay.

—description from the designer

name: Werewolf Duel
description:
Werewolf Duel makes a moderator unnecessary, conversation unnecessary, many people unnecessary, location and a lot of time also unnecessary.
It is an entirely new type of werewolf game.

Four if turned up a number card in the village card only one are hidden werewolf card in without blind villagers score!
Scores of people wolf side and would turn the people wolf card!

Bluff and if each other reading is a psychological warfare game each other do our tactical!

■ overview

This is, just before the man wolf of eating human slipped's wolf game begins in the village story.

Among the rumors that neighboring villages has become a victim of human wolf game is full,
If you want to make sure that was the journey people wolves will hear the information of the village that is the next target.

Already eluded the eyes of the werewolf that is sunk into the village, let's escape as much as possible of the villagers from the village!
However, there will be a village that is not lurking human wolf in the mistake of rumors. There it becomes in the way of escape and look of doubt!

—description from the designer
categories: Abstract Strategy, Bluffing, Horror, Number, Party Game
mechanics: Push Your Luck, Secret Unit Deployment

name: Tutti Frutti
description:
Tutti frutti is a cooperative and dexterity game.
Players stack cubes according to the logic of domino, trying not to drop them.
The box contains 21 fruit cubes (each cube has 2 fruits), 3 die cubes, 4 fruit boxes and 4 discs.
The game has 3 modes depending on the target age:
- 2+ years: children stack the cubes as they want or arrange them horizontally forming a fruit snake.
- 3+ years: the cubes must be stacked in 4 fruit boxes, following the rules of the domino. The cardboard disks can be put as wild cards among the various cubes. Players win if they stack all 21 cubes, lose if a cube falls.
- 4+ years: play as in the intermediate mode. In addition, the current player throws a die cube. The face of the die determines in which box the fruit is to be placed. Playing with fewer boxes increases the difficulty level.

-description from designer
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition

name: La sfida del coding
description:
La sfida del coding is a game to take the first steps in programming, using only cardboard components.

Initially, the game proposes 24 puzzles to solve in which players have to move their robot to the destination using the directional cards: the puzzles are of increasing difficulty and present, by hand, additional elements such as walls and special cards.
The game contains 4 plastic robots, 4 modular boards, 24 tiles and 132 cards to challenge the others in races that are always different and full of twists.

Each player has 7 cards in his hand and he secretly plays 3, simultaneously with the opponents: players turn one card at a time and make their robots perform the corresponding action.

There are 3 progressive game modes: in the basic version, only directional cards are used, in the middle version there are also shots and in the advanced one there are special cards such as routines, shields and magnets.

The tiles can be arranged as desired on the boards to give life to different paths.

The particular thing of the advanced version is that, in addition to creating paths as desired, players can also customize the decks, choosing the special cards to play with.

-description from designer
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Maze, Racing
mechanics: Action Queue, Grid Movement, Modular Board, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Topa Topa
description: Topa Topa combines card drafting with Tetris-style gameplay as players draft a card from a hand given to them by their left- or right-hand neighbor (depending on the current round of the game), then they reveal that card and draw that object on their individual player board. The game lasts three rounds, and in each round you score for completing levels, using different shapes in your area, and doing other things as well. Coins allow you to break the rules for drafting and drawing.

name: Doo-Doo Wars
description:
Doo-Doo Wars from Stinky Games is the new strategy board game that’s outrageously fun to play with friends or the whole family.

Launch your character’s doo-doo into neighbors’ yards while protecting your own! Everyone takes turns rolling the dice. If a player’s yard gets completely covered in doo-doo, they’re out. Last one standing with the cleanest yard wins!

—description from the designer

name: Courier: Spiel'18 Promotion tile
description:
This is a promotion tile for Courier, given out at SPIEL '18.

This tile has a special ability. When preparing for the game, place it in the center of the town.

Power: This tile can be pushed into any direction in town, regardless of the location of your courier.

-description from the publisher
categories: Abstract Strategy, Expansion for Base-game, Transportation

name: Fair Trade
description:
Through conscious choices, you as a consumer have the power to improve the world. Will you be able to produce and trade consciously and economically for a better world?

You play both a farmer, investing in fair production, and a trader, buying fairly produced goods. You do this through secret bidding. The higher your farmer bid, the more you will earn from the trader bids. The higher your trader bid, the more fair trade markers you will earn. You win by earning the most fair trade markers without going bankrupt.

The game encourages conscious consumption but also emphasizes the economic realities necessary to enable this. The simultaneous bidding minimizes downtime and maximizes tension. Simple rules and language independence makes the game accessible for the whole family.

—description from the designer

name: Find the Treasure: The Card Game
description:
The cards of the game has two faces, a map face and a clue face. The game is played in 2 phases.

In the map phase, you play cards either as map cards to an island or as clue cards to your hand. The map cards tell you the terrain of island and the clue cards tell you where the treasures are in relation to the terrain. You may only play two of your cards as clue cards so choose them wisely!

You also play 1 pirate flag to serve as a starting point. The later you play it, the sooner you get to start the next phase!

In the treasure phase, you take turns to move from any pirate flag. If you find a map card that matches any of your clue cards, you exchange the clue card with the map card and take 1 treasure. But hurry, other pirates may beat you to the treasure!

The game ends when a round is completed without any found treasures. The winner is the pirate who finds the most treasures.

—description from the designer

name: Peoples: Civilizations
description:
Over the time of history, tribes of different peoples move across the Earth. They found settlements, establish foreign relations and develop civilizations. Each people shapes its unique civilization and develops its unique abilities. Eventually they will all meet and their meetings will tell which civilization that is destined to stand the test of time.

There are six victory conditions linked to the six civilization traits. Culture victory is won by placing all your culture tokens, Economic victory by collecting one of each resource, Military victory by placing all your tribes etc.

The game is played on modular map where new areas are added and merged as your civilization grows and expands.

Each turn you engage one tribe only. A tribe may either produce resources in its area or spend civilization points to take one of six civilization actions. Certain development cards improve certain actions.

1. Civics lets you build settlements or activate all tribes in a settlement in a turn.
2. Culture lets you place culture tokens, which give discounts on civilization points.
3. Economy lets you exchange resources with adjacent peoples to collect more valuable sets.
4. Military lets you attack adjacent peoples to plunder their resources.
5. Religion lets you place religion tokens, which give discounts on development cards.
6. Science lets your tribes take actions in areas further away from their own areas.

When all tribes are engaged (but not before!), you must disengage them with a Revolution action. This is also the action where you grow your population and acquire civilization points and development cards. This also serves as a catch-up mechanic, since larger civilizations gets more productive actions but have to wait longer for the next Revolution action.

In Peoples, you are faced with tough tactical and strategic questions. Which civilization traits do you prioritize to achieve your goals? Which development cards do you acquire to adapt to the changing conditions? Which civilizations do you cooperate with and which do you compete with? The history will judge whether you answered the questions right or wrong.

name: Merkator
description:
An intelligence game that copy the marketing strategies companies use.
The one who win more money in this 'monopolesque' game will be the greatest businessman.

name: Fireside Football
description:
Football (soccer) game, probably from the 1950’s. This is a board game using a die for two or more players. Players roll a die and then move according to directional arrows or instructions on the board

—user summary

name: Barnyard Race
description:
Barnyard Race, a thrilling race at the farm!
Reach the finish line on the racetrack, by rolling as many of the same animal on the dice as you can. End de race with the rooster sprint.

HOW TO PLAY
On your turn, roll the dice by putting them into the dice silo. You may roll them up to three times, trying to obtain as many of the same animal as you can.
The rooster on the dice is special; it acts as wild, helping you to improve your roll.
MOVING ON THE RACETRACK
If a player gets 5 of a kind, as in example above, where he has obtained 5 rabbits, he moves his rabbit token 5 spaces along the racetrack.
It's a relay race, players must use a different animal token for each turn. On their next turn, the race continue where their last animal token left off.

FINISHING THE RELAY RACE WITH THE ROOSTER SPRINT
Only after all 5 animal tokens have been played, players take one or more additional turns by using their special rooster token. Each player rolls the 5 dice once only, trying to get as many roosters to move their token toward the finish line. The first player to reach the finish line, wins the Barnyard Race!

—description from the publisher
publishers: Dumont Games Inc., Jeux Dumont Inc

name: Animalea
description:
Look for trios of animals or colors!

You must be the first to shout ANIMALEA! Concentrate, combine cards correctly and accumulate trios to win! Two games of perception and speed in one can.

—description from the publisher

name: Enclave
description:
Definitions

Region: any distinct area of the board, consisting only of empty points, and surrounded by one color of stone in conjunction with at most 2 board edges.

Loose stone: any stones not outlining a region. Loose stones are captured when surrounded by an enemy region

Objective: Control the most territory (stones + regions). The game ends with two successive passes

Gameplay: Players alternate placing a stone of either color on an empty point of the board. If doing so forms any regions the following conditions must be met:


all enemy stones within the prospective regions are loose stones.
there must be at least one loose stone in each prospective region to be captured.


Note: You may never play stones into an established region

Pie Rule: On his first move, the second player may opt to play as the opposite color in lieu of making a move.

—description from the designer

name: Kontakt
description: A tile game where players compete to add their triangular shaped tiles to the play area. Scoring points occurs when the values on your tile and the adjacent tile are a multiple of 5 within one color. Other rules are unclear as they are not in English.

name: Mythos of Legends
description:
Mythos of Legends is a tabletop wargame of grand strategy involving gods, mythical beasts, legendary heroes and mortal soldiers. Players choose their faction from Ancient Greece, Ancient Rome, Dark Age Pagans, Ancient Egypt and Eldritch Abominations. Each faction has a unique roster and playstyle, further affected by the player's choice of deity.

The Mythos Board is the domain of the gods. Each player has one 35mm scale deity model which affects the rolls that they need to make on the battlefield. By way of example, soldiers that follow Ares will fight more effectively in combat than those who follow Hades, but Hades' followers are much tougher to kill. Each deity also has unique abilities called Divine Interventions, such as Osiris resurrecting friendly models or Loki stealing the enemy's dice, meaning that overall the player's choice of deity has a massive effect on how their army performs. The gods are locked in their own struggle of wills and moods as they move around the Mythos Board. Their position grants further bonuses to their followers depending on what stats the player thinks are most important at the current moment in time.

The soldiers, beasts and heroes fight on the battlefield in the name of their deity. Legendary Units such as the Lernean Hydra, Julius Caesar and Ragnar Lothbrok are represented by 15mm scale miniautres, while ordinary soldiers are sculpted in 10mm on ranked bases. Players secretly assign their units order tokens and then activate them alternately, carrying out the order. Success or failure comes from dice rolls based on four stats - Wrath, Wisdom, Swiftness and Determination - with the number of dice to be rolled based on the unit's profile, equipment and the position of the patron deity on the Mythos Board. The deity's stats determine the roll for a success.

The turn structure is set up so that players roll off for priority, move their deities and attempt divine interventions, secretly assign orders to their units, carry out their orders alternately and then finally take break checks and check for victory conditions as determined by the scenario.

—description from the publisher

name: Astrocalipsis
description:
Astrocalipsis is a new fantasy universe in which everything known is under the control of the implacable Astroangels' Empire. Your condemned world seeks its strongest heroes, a team of virtuous which will give it an opportunity to continue their existence.

In this new adventure you will be a Guardian and take control of three Heroes, you must manage them to made them stronger so you can defeat the most powerful creaures of this world and beat your oponents.

Traveling through Vestigia´s land you must collect five of the eight Astrocalipsis' badges to be the winner, you will get these badges killing creatures, controlling territories, defeating your opponents and achieving five others specials challenges, but there is only exist one of each badges, so be smart to chose which and when get it.

Astrocalipsis is a game designed for two players, but its allow up to six players, playing in teams or solo mode.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Dice Rolling, Set Collection

name: Raiffeisen
description:
In this cooperative board game players are taken back into the world of F. W. Raiffeisen. You 'll get to know the hard way of life in those days and experience, how a normal mayor by the name of Raiffeisen started alleviating misery and distress of normal people in 1845 and developed his concept of the cooperative idea, exactly in line with his motto „What can't be done alone, can be done together".

During the course of time, this cooperative idea co-founded by Raiffeisen, has spread all round the world and since 2016, has been declared by UNESCO as „Intangible Cultural Heritage".

The game board consists of 8 puzzle boards, which when together form a large landscape map. Here, the players travel through the villages where Raiffeisen implemented his ideas. Different fields of work present times of waiting, because the tasks set can only be overcome together. Players experience through 53 fields, what Raiffeisen undertook against hunger and misery. Those players falling behind are taken by the hand of solidarity and given the chance to carry on playing. Players with „Solvency Problems" are given financial help through solidarity. Single moves mostly affect the other players, so that all participants are ensnared in this exciting journey through time — right from the beginning, all the way through to the end.

At the end of the game, there is not only one winner and one thing is for certain: this lively game is lots of fun and imparts to children as well as grown-ups lots of interesting facts about Friedrich Wilhelm Raiffeisen and the times he lived in. Game board size and length of play can be decided upon. Decide how much time you have and then take the plunge into Raiffeisen's World for as long as you like: one, two or even for three hours.

—from the back of the box

name: Ragnarök: 2 Player Card Game
description:
Ragnarök is a 2-player tarot-card battle game inspired by Norse mythology. Players will choose to play as the Jötnar led by Loki, or the Æsir led by Óðinn and will face-off across five ancient worlds.

The game features Divinity Cards depicting 20 characters that each have a strength value and Rune Cards that have both a strength value and ability.

The combined strength of Divinity Cards and Rune Cards played in each world will determine who controls it. The player who gains control of the most worlds over 3 rounds claims victory.

Players will need to decide where they deploy their strongest Divinity Cards and whether to play Rune Cards for their strength or abilities to alter the outcome of the battle.

—description from the publisher

name: Oscar Bait
description:
Oscar Bait is an 18 card microgame and part of The Stocking Stuffer Collection.

You are a star actor looking to earn the accolades you so richly deserve. Prove your talent by earning top roles and taking down your rivals to keep them from outshining you. You'll have to find the right balance between taking auditions and talking down your competition if you want to take home the prize!

Playing Oscar Bait takes place in two distinct phases - Audition and Sabotage. In the audition phase each player drafts a choice role or scathing gossip from their hand and passes the rest along. Roles a player places into their schedule are worth points at the end, but are at risk of being lost or stolen based on the Sabotage cards played. Determine the right track for success and you'll end up with the best schedule in the end, but judge poorly and you may end up a bit player in someone else's story!

—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Monsterpocalypse Miniatures Game: G.U.A.R.D. Unit Expansion 1
description:
Shattering the sound barrier to arrive on the scene accompanied by sonic booms, Strike Fighters make up the air force of G.U.A.R.D. Each pilot is a fearless daredevil with his finger on the trigger of smart missile technology that can circumvent heavy cover.

Rocket Choppers trade the raw speed of Strike Fighters for flexibility of engagement. Armed with rocket pods, they adroitly weave between buildings to shake off pursuit and dodge incoming fire while spotting threats for more powerful units to engage.

Contains:

Strike Fighter (4)

Rocket Chopper (1)

—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Miniatures, Science Fiction

name: Monsterpocalypse Miniatures Game: G.U.A.R.D. Unit Expansion 2
description:
The G-Tank is a solid fighting machine that utilizes its sturdy tank treads to roll over any obstacle that would impair its movement.

Repair Trucks crewed by skilled G.U.A.R.D. engineers wage an endless battle against devastation as they rush to restore crumbling structures and save the civilians within.

Contains:

G-Tank (4)

Repair Truck (1)

—description from the publisher

name: Monsterpocalypse Miniatures Game: Planet Eaters Unit Expansion 2
description:
Belchers are rotund agents of destruction sent to intercept any of the fighting forces interfering with the Planet Eaters’ rampages. Capable of moving surprisingly quickly on their stubby legs, Belchers can spew out balls of flaming plasma like living artillery.

Crawlers are bug-like monsters whose saliva can melt earth and stone, and they are able to swim through the molten sludge they create. Suicidal and disposable, they retaliate to attack by exploding in a blaze of plasma energy, obliterating everything around them.

Contains:

Belcher (4)

Crawler (1)

—description from the publisher

name: Boundary Waters Canoe Trip: An Adventure Travel Game
description:
Players go on imaginary canoe trips through the Quetico-Superior--a portion of southern Canada and northern Minnesota, the Boundary Waters. the travel routes are ever changing, determined by the players and the cards they draw. The first player to complete a trip is the winner.

—user summary
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Planetary Conquest: The Supplemental Card Game
description:
Planetary Conquest is a Supplemental Card Game where 2 players will vie for control of a newfound galaxy. Players will build their own 80 card decks and go head-to-head in a strategic game of area control, hand management, deck management, and active combat using dice rolling. The winner will be determined by who is first able to seize control of the nine planets, or by whoever has the most galaxy control when one player runs out of cards.

New supplemental sets will be released each month allowing players to expand their collections as well as their futuristic arsenal allowing them to become the greatest conqueror of the galaxy.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Open Drafting, Set Collection

name: AZAD the Game
description:
From Iain M.Banks Sci-Fi novel "The Player of Games".
Up to ten players, with alliances, intrigue, concerted action, pacts and treachery.
Move the pieces with their unique movements on the chessboard, fight using action cards and dice. Conquer the territory earning the value points and annex the resources to your side. Expand your sphere of influences to the other player territory and destroy the enemy forces. Build, transform and use the space you have conquered to help You to collect enemy pieces, territory and possession.
Earn the highest points or remain the only player in the game.
Three different main chess boards, three smaller, pieces, cards and dice.

—description from the designer

name: Light of Morning Sun
description:
This is a Sugoroku (roll-and-move) type of game published in 1905 to celebrate Japan's success in the Russo-Japanese war.

The lavishly illustrated 22-space track on the board follows the progress of the war on both land and sea, mixed with a few scenes from the home front, with an un-numbered corner panel showing a Japanese diplomat facing down his Russian counterpart.

—user summary

name: Shonen Kurabu Furoku Orimpiku Nekkyo Yugiban
description:
This is an unusual Japanese game published in 1936 and themed on that year's Olympic Games in Berlin.

It is a game of maneouver for 4 players representing Japan, the United States, Great Britain and France. It is played on a circular board, with spaces dividing a series of concentric rings. The innermost ring features four symbols for four other coutries: Germany, Norway, Finland and Canada.

Each player has four tokens, and must try to move them across the board to an objective space immediately behind the starting spaces of the player opposite.

The back of the game sheet features head-and-shoulders photographs of 51 members of the Japanese Olympic team.

—user summary

name: Child Soldier
description:
This is a WWII roll-and-move game that encouraged Japanese children to think of potential military roles.

Five children are shown in the lower right, and each one follows a distinct training path through the many images of military life shown on the board, leading to one of five service branches: Infantry, Artillery, Signals, Armor and Air Force. The winner is the first player to complete training in their chosen branch.

The game included in an edition a children's magazine published by the Asahi Shimbun media empire. The back of the game sheet shows other pages of the magazine, and there are center staple holes showing that it was a centerfold pull-out.

The absence of any naval roles shows that this game was army-sponsored, and illustrates the deep divide between Japan's land and sea forces at the time.

—user summary

name: Boys Club Warship Game
description:
This is a relatively simple game of naval maneuver published by Japan's Kodansha media group within its Boys Club magazine.

The board is diamond shaped, with an extra triangle extending from the right and left side points. Players move their pieces from their own triangular base across the board, seeking to occupy their opponent's base.

name: Sekai Rekyo So Yugi
description:
This is a very rare and unusual Japanese game published during WWI. It uses traditional Shogi (Japanese chess) game pieces, but is designed to be played by eight players rather than the usual two.

The playing positions represent all of the major powers involved in the Great War: Germany, Austria-Hungary, France, Italy, Great Britain, the United States, Russia and Japan. Two countries are set up in each corner of the square board, but have unique entry spaces for their pieces.

Each player receives only four playing pieces, and the board is set up so that they must fight their way from their home country space around the board to their home flag space.

—user summary

name: Halt! Schmugglerschiff!
description:
Ships carry boxes and goods loaded from player to player, so it's important to buy 12 identical pieces of cargo, and those who reach this first are winners.

—description from the publisher (translated)

name: Granny's Knickers
description:
Granny loves a bargain. She also loves jumble sales. But what she doesn’t love, what really gets Granny’s Knickers in a twist, is when someone else grabs the best items before her. Who will be the first to get their hands on Granny’s Knickers?

OBJECT OF THE GAME:
Channel your inner Granny to snatch the best items from the jumble pile before the other grannies. The Granny who gets the highest score wins.

GAME-PLAY:
Players complete simultaneously to find desirable items from a pile of cards scattered facedown in the play area. The first player to find the item wins the round. After nine rounds all players hunt for the ultimate prize - Granny’s Knickers. The player with the highest score wins the game.

The game also includes a 2-3 player variant where players must find several items from a list before trying to find Granny’s Knickers. In the variant it is the first player to find Granny’s Knickers in a ‘race to the lace’ that wins.

name: MiniCity Postmen
description:
Each player is a mailman from the city and his goal is to deliver the nine cards, in his corresponding block according to the color. The winner of the game will be the one who first delivers all his cards.

Tour the city using vocabulary in English related to places, actions that we perform in each of them, questions and indications about how to get from one place to another, prepositions and key expressions about this content, consolidating reading, listening and listening skills. oral production in this language.

Contents:
Places and elements of a city
Trades and occupations
Prepositions of place
Indications and questions on how to go from one
place to another
Means of urban transport

Skills:
Speaking, listening, reading, pronunciation

name: Crocoparty Adult edition
description:
The game consists of 99 cards with challenging tasks of different difficulty level - each has five words or collocations.

Takes about 30 seconds to understand rules.
Fun, noisy and sociable.
You'd better not forget to put a video of this on tube!


All cards in this edition are XXX themed.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Mature / Adult, Party Game, Travel, Word Game

name: Cowboy Rodeo
description:
The goal of the game is to collect 5 letter cards that form the word "RODEO". The players move their figures (Leyla models) around the game board. Movement is controlled by a die. In the spaces marked with a letter, the player collect a corresponding letter card. If a player gets on a space marked with "1", he gets to collect one sadle card, which is used as a wild card. The space marked with "2" causes the player to miss 3 turn or pay a saddle card. If a player gets on a "3" he has to return one card.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Wer gewinnt die Rundfahrt Köln: Taunus – Köln?
description:
The players travel from Köln (cologne) to the Taunus Mountains and back. Movement is determined by a die. The first player back in Köln wins the game.

The game was published between 1960 and 1964 a a promotional game for the Ford Taunus P3 (17 M), also called "Ford Badewanne" (bathtub), which is pictured on the game board.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Role Playing, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Thomas the Tank Engine and Friends Luggage on the Line
description:
A family game where you play one of four engines from Thomas the Tank Engine series. The passengers' luggage have been scattered over the tracks. You are competing to retrieve the most luggage.

Each turn you insert a new track tile into the board shifting all tiles in that row or column. Then you move your engine along one of the available routes on the board. If you reach the current item of luggage being searched for, you collect it scoring a point. The person who collects the most luggage throughout the game wins.

—user summary

This is an IP specific version of Ravensburger's Labyrinth.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Network and Route Building, Tile Placement

name: Market Master
description:
Market Master is a quick playing card game about controlling and dominating international markets and industries. Game play involves playing market cards to claim control of either regions or industries, manipulating market limits, or developing key growth industries. Markets may only be developed to fixed limits (based on the number of players) and thus it is essential for players to balance their limited investments with efforts to manipulate the market limits. Controlling a growth industry provides players with additional cards with which to plan, but growth industries can shift rapidly.

Business is both a regional and an industry affair. Although each region and industry operates within its own context, there are strong connections that interweave to create the global market. Knowing how just one market works can earn you a fortune, but to be a true economic titan one must know how to manipulate all the markets together. As the newly appointed director of an international investment company, you have a simple goal… dominate the world markets and claim the title of Market Master.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Hand Management, Market, Set Collection

name: GROK-or-GUMP
description:
GROK-or-GUMP contains 3 games in 1. All 3 games use a special dual-suited 30 card deck called a GROK Deck. Each card has a Major Suit and a Minor Suit. There are 3 Major suits (each with 10 cards) and 5 Minor suits in the deck (each with 6 cards).

The 3 games included are each distinctly different from each other.

GROK: A trick-taking with escalating bids in which 1 player takes on all other players. Players bid on the number of cards of either Major or Minor suits they will capture during the round. A player wins the bid points if they are successful; however, if a player obtains a result that is better than the highest bid at the start of the round, all other players score points per that result.

GUMP: A hand-elimination game in which players attempt to be the first player to play all of their cards - or - be the player with the least cards in hand when the round ends. This game makes use of 18 supplemental GROK Rule cards that specify how cards must be played. If a player is unable to play according to the rule, they add all played cards to their hand and flip up a new rule. The game ends when a player plays their last card or if all 18 rules have been used.

GROK-or-GUMP: A pattern-recognition and social deduction style game. This game uses a small number of GROK Rule cards and a hand of 5 cards. Prior to starting the round, all players secretly decide if they will follow 1 of the face up rule cards or follow none of them. Once all players have decided which way they will play, players each play 1 card down in front of themselves. Players may then choose to place a bet on any player as to which way they are playing. Play continues until all 5 cards are played. Players score points based on when and if the other players' bets were correct.

From the Publisher:

Some people are natural players; some are just plain lucky. And though it can be hard to tell them apart, at least each has a name.

GROK:(n) A player who understands a game intuitively and completely and thus obtains success through skill.

GUMP:(n) A player who plays without obvious thought or plays randomly but nonetheless has consistent success.

Not sure which you are? The games included in GROK-or-GUMP will figure it out for you!

—description from the publisher

name: Octad
description:
Octad, "the strategic game of number-sequences," is a 2-player game played on an 8×8 grid. Each player Starts with 16 chips, comprising two sets of identical chips numbered 1 through 8. Chips are placed on the grid at the beginning of the game, along the two rows closest to the player.

Chips move one space in each turn. Odd numbers move diagonally; even numbers move orthogonally.

The object of the game is to create simple numerical sequences on your opponent's side of the board while trying to stop your opponent from doing the same on your side of the board.

A sequence is a straight-line chain of at least three numbers. The number chain can be set up in any straight line, orthogonally or diagonally. Sequences are declared and cannot afterward be altered by addition or subtraction of a number. But additional chains can be formed at an angle to declared sequences.

Play ends when a total of three sequences has been completed between the two players. The player with the highest score wins.

—user summary

name: Don't Get Splat
description:
Competing in the inaugural Splat paintball tournament, you must outmaneuver your opponents and take the least amount of hits. By drafting cards, players must manipulate and use the card abilities to get the lowest score to win the coveted Splat Cup.

The game is played over 3 Rounds, with scoring performed at the end of each round. On a players turn, they must draft a card and add it to their tableau. When they draft, they must consider the points on the card, the card ability, it's colour, turn order and the Round cards that manipulate the gameplay and scoring.

name: Farmatropic
description:
Farmatropic is a deck-building farm-building game with a colourful tropical theme.

In Farmatropic you build your farm field by field and barn by barn in front of you on the table whilst filling your deck with actions allowing for increased efficiency. You use these farm and barn spaces to grow crops and raise animals using a turn-card method to track plant growth and live-stock progress. There a numerous cards you can acquire that permanently affix to farms and barns to increase defences against other players Shenanigans.

Players must manage their farm on the table in front you while also balancing their decks with on-board cards, in hand defences, crops, animals and currency.

The winner is the player to acquire the highest value of wealth by the time either the farm card or barn card decks are exhausted.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Open Drafting, Tile Placement, Worker Placement

name: Materials & War
description:
Material & War is a card game that can be played with two to four players and varies in play time. It is a strategic game that is quick to learn and easy to play, meaning it is suited for both experienced people looking for a quick and new game and for new people looking to experience a simple strategic war game.

This card game pits two to four players against each other in different game modes. Pick your house card carefully because it will give you a slight advantage in one way or another. Roll the dice to gather materials to build up your kingdom or fight against others.

Theme is a past century gathering and war game.

Game-play is simple, first three rounds consist of gather materials to strengthen your kingdom. After the third round is over you may choose to attack other kingdoms or continue to gather material.

The goal of the game is to destroy all other kingdoms and being the last one standing.

—description from the designer

name: Champions: Hills of Glory
description:
Champions: Hills of Glory is tactical arena style card/board game for 2 to 4 players where each takes the role of a commander in a fantasy battlefield who is ordered to capture and hold a strategically positioned small hill. Commanders will send their units up the hill battling the opponents’ in a 4x4 field, trying to keep as many as possible alive while assisting them with their unique abilities and specialty cards. Each unit in the field will grant their commander 1 victory point at the end of each round. The first player to score 24 victory points claims the hill and becomes the winner.

The game consists of two types of cards; units (of levels 1 to 5) and specialty cards (of five types: combat, tactics, sorcery, trickery and faith). Each player chooses a commander and takes the appropriate template. On their commander templates, players can track their power (the resource needed to play cards), their actions and their abilities (each commander has two). Commanders aslo have one or two specializations each, noting which specialty card types they're favoring. Units are set up on 5 stacks - one for each level and players will reveal the topmost of each level and place it in front of its stack. Specialty cards are also separated in 5 stacks by type.

During a game round each player will take two turns. When one's 1st turn comes, he or she will choose and execute two of the four available actions (any of them in any order). Once done, turn passes to the next player and so on. When his or hers second turn comes, he or she will execute the remaining two actions. The actions player can take are: A) Increase Power: player increases his or her power by 3. If he has a specialty card in hand, he can discard one to increase the power for 2 more. A player's power can't be more than 6 or less than 0. B) Draw: player can draw up to two cards whether they are units, specialties or a combination of both. If a player wants to draw a unit, she must pay the unit's level in power. She can either draw from the revealed ones or the top face-down unit of a stack. To draw a specialty card the player needs to pay no power. She can just draw one from any stack plus one of the stack she specializes. C) Play: player can play up to two cards from their hand, being a unit, a specialty or a combination of both. To play a specialty card he must have at least as many power as the card indicates (though he doesn't spend it). Specialty cards can empower friendly units or effect negatively the opponent ones. Each specialty type focuses on different gameplay aspects (damage, buff, debuff, heal, extra activations etc). To play a unit he puts it face-down on his starting area. Opponents can see now that he is about to send a unit of X level (it's typed on the card back) in the field. D)Command: the meat of the game. During this action the player can activate up to 2 of her units in the field. Units have 4 characteristics indicating how long they can move, how many dice they roll per attack and what type of attack they have (determines its range), its defence (how difficult is to get hit) and its life (how many damage it can sustain). They also have special abilities that they can use at that moment. When a unit attacks another, the controlling player rolls dice equal to its attack. For each roll that was equal or higher than the target's defense, he scores a hit. The number of hits is the damage inflicted upon the opponent unit. If a player has more than 2 units in the field and he didn't activate them, he can put them under "defend command". They can now act during an opponent turn! Special condition effects such as daze, poison, bleed or shatter can be applied to units via abilities or specialty cards, to spice up the game and give it more tactical depth.

When all players have played 2 turns each, the round ends and they count score - 1 point for each of their units remain on the field. If a player has 24 points at that time, he or she is the winner.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Variable Player Powers

name: 80 Tallsspillet
description: Trivia game with questions from the 80's.

name: Restless Souls
description:
Restless Souls is a competitive dungeon crawler with strong deck builder elements for 2 to 6 players. The game is set in a medieval fantasy world controlled by ancient souls.

Players control one of many different heroes, each with their own unique skills and talents. All in search of great power to finally conquer the Shrine of Souls to become a godlike soul and write new history. Oppose monsters and fellow heroes whilst helping out the population and discovering ancient ruins to gain experience, gems and talent points. As each game is randomly generated you will have to shift tactics every time you enter this fast paced strategic adventure for power.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Area Movement, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Cooperative Game, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Open Drafting, Role Playing

name: Rushmore Sports Edition
description:
Rushmore Sports is an sports trivia card game prefect for anyone and everyone who loves to argue about sports. Do you know someone who can relive every play in the 1968 Superbowl but can't remember to take out the trash? This game is their dream.

Playing is easy. There are three types of cards, Category Cards, You Choose Cards and Debatable Cards. Each player takes turns picking a card from the pile and reading it aloud. The players each answer the question until there is only one person left with a correct answer. That person wins the card. For Debatable Cards players share their thoughts on, for example, What is your Mt. Rushmore of Best Athletes in History? The person with the best answer wins by popular vote. The first person to collect 10 man-cards is crowned the winner.

It is the perfect Party Game for sports lovers or as a staple on any man-cave coffee table.

—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Party Game, Sports, Trivia

name: Shieldbearer
description:
“Rules for ancient combat simulation.”
This is a rule set for miniatures battles at an army scale. Units are comprised of 2 - 12 Elements with each element being upwards of 200 men or horses, single elephants, or 20 or so chariots.
It includes a points system for balancing armies and terrain, and for calculating victory.
Movement and ranges are calculated as multiples of element base size.
The rules are simple and straightforward with consideration given to different arms and armour in combat as well as ‘Determination’(which is factored from morale), organization, and depth of ranks.

The main distinguishing characteristic of these rules is perhaps the necessity to Order each unit, the considerations for changing orders, and the fact that troops under attack orders must move forward. Thus initial Orders, especially,(which may include ‘if’,’until’,’and then’ clauses) are very important.

—user summary

name: Crussato
description:
Crussato is a game played on the standard 8x8 chessboard. It is designed to be a very simple to learn, yet highly strategical, board game. Its minimal and simple ruleset allows new players of all ages to rapidly engage in action, while reserving great challenges for the chessboard veterans.

It is a 2 player game and each player gets sixteen pieces. Fourteen pieces (two sets of 7) marked with a number between 1 ~ 7 and and two pieces marked with an X. The X marked pieces are called the Dukes. All pieces are free to move in Queen style movements. Their imprinted numbers define their step limitations. Dukes also move freely, but only one step at a time. The goal of the game is for each player to eliminate both opponent Dukes.

The game is played on the above three simple rules, plus one optional rule for advanced players. This optional rule limits the movement of a piece, after it crosses the middle line, and requires it to stay at the opponent side of the board until the end of the game. Draw cases are possible and described in the games ruleset.

—description from the designer

name: Z War One: Exodus – Delta 6 Aftermath
description: Hero & infected cards for using Exodus miniatures in Damnation games. A special campaign "Delta 6 - Aftermath" using assets from all existing Z War One content + 3 additional game tiles.
mechanics: Action Points, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling

name: Z War One: Damnation – Infected Heroes
description: In campaign games, the death of a hero ends their mission. In director games however, any fallen heroes immediately jump back into the game as a 'newborn' fast zombie & join the forces of the evil director.
categories: Comic Book / Strip, Expansion for Base-game, Horror, Zombies
mechanics: Action Points, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling

name: Super Bunny Wars
description:
Fight for victory in a super awesome draft-battle game. Mix and match cards from seven different factions to combine the perfect team of legendary, epic and common bunnies. Create powerful combos, go on the defensive, or just fight with raw attack power.
But beware.... There are many plot twist cards to mess op your plans.

Knock-out your opponent(s) bunnies in a strategic battle to score victory points. Scoring the most victory points over a 2 round battle will make you the winner of a game of Super Bunny Wars

Super Bunny Wars is an ode to the late 80’s, early 90’s cartoons we loved as kids. Made into a Draft-Battle game.

—description from the publisher

name: Black Cat
description:
Black Cat: Dice Game For Adults

Object: To beat the Black Cat

Bet: Beverage of choice or Halloween candy

Roll dice to determine who is the Black Cat.

The Black Cat rolls 2 dice from the cup (without showing the results.)

Each player rolls 1 die.

The player bets his number to be either between Black Cat's 2 dice
or outside.

If the bet is correct, player wins.
If equal to either of Black Cat's 2 dice, player gets a "push."

When Black Cat loses, player to the right is the new Black Cat.

name: The Immortal Wars
description:
The Universal Tabletop Strategy Game of Gods, Monsters, and Machines

From the mountains of Olympus to the depths of the darkest oceans, they awoke from their long slumber. Gods, demi-gods, titans, demons and other-worldly beings from your nightmares came from myth and became reality. Alliances formed and the stage was set for war like never before seen on Earth, or even beneath it.

Mankind has found itself between colossal forces of legendary power. C’thulean terrors rise from the oceans as gods ride winged beasts into battle. Meanwhile, the armies of humanity fight simply to survive. With the awakening of the gods, long dormant demi-gods, mutants, and freaks, have unleashed chaos on the world.

This new world disorder has left many cities burning husks while the people flee to the remaining bastions of safety and security.

The Immortal Wars is a table-top strategy game mixing fantasy, modern, science-fiction, and superhero genres. Do battle with tanks, infantry, hovercraft, jet fighters, giant mecha, mutants, superhumans, and abominations.

—description from the rulebook

The Immortal Wars is played on a flat surface (a minimum of 4' x 6' is recommended) with distances measured in inches (the game uses the curiously mixed ratio of 1 inch to 7.5 meters). Combatants are represented by miniature figures (representing single units) with an associated "unit card" providing data and tracking damage, etc. Combat and movement occur in rounds, each round representing about six seconds. Random results are generated using only twelve-sided dice (d12). Several dice in different colors are recommended.

The game assumes two "sides" in each combat, each controlled by one (optionally more) player. Each player builds their force by purchasing units with points. One player is the defender; the other player is the attacker. Setup follows a pre-determined "scenario" (setup guide).

During each round, initiative is determined. The losing player moves 1/2 of their units; the winning player moves 1/2 of their units; the losing player move the remainder of their units; the winning player moves the remainder of their units. Most units can move vertically as well as horizontally. Units utilize a somewhat simplified method of two-dimensional facing. Attacks are resolved at the end of a movement, if legal - this means the player that loses initiative will perform the first attacks of the round.

The game supports a wide range of combatant types, from mecha to armor to monsters. Many units have special abilities that invoke special rules. A variety of terrain and status situations may apply. The game also provides a wide variety of optional rules (including adjustments to 25mm scale).

Play persists until one player achieves pre-determined victory results or eliminates the other player.

The game document includes a large number of print-and-play tokens to mark various effects on the battlefield. Also included are blank, print-and-play unit cards.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Player Elimination, Simulation, Variable Player Powers

name: The Immortal Wars: Humans
description:
A Faction List for tabletop warfare in the age of gods, monsters, and technology!

In a desperate bid for survival, humans turned to technology to save them from the ever-growing threats of the Immortals and Beasts.

[This print-and-play component] is a list of official units available for The Immortal Wars. While official, it is incomplete. We highly encourage you to modify units and create new units and share them. If you choose to make alternate versions of these units and share them in your own document, we ask that you change the names on the stat cards for clarity.

—description from the rulebook
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Print & Play, Wargame

name: The Immortal Wars: Thuleans
description:
A Faction List for tabletop warfare in the age of gods, monsters, and technology!

Twisted forms in the deepest dark of the oceans rose to reclaim the lands.

[This print-and-play component] is a list of official units available for The Immortal Wars. While official, it is incomplete. We highly encourage you to modify units and create new units and share them. If you choose to make alternate versions of these units and share them in your own document, we ask that you change the names on the stat cards for clarity.

—description from the rulebook
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Print & Play, Wargame

name: Namn Memo
description: Namn Memo is a memory game with a twist. All tiles have a name on them, and among the tiles there is a tile with the same name spelled backwards. If a player flip two tiles with the same name, the player keep those cards. The player with most points in the end is the winner.

name: With Sword and Bayonet
description:
A set of Colonial-era skirmish rules for miniatures wargaming. Each figure represents an individual. The rules are suitable for use with 54mm or 25mm figures, using respective scales of 1"=1m or 1cm=1m. The rules system uses percentile dice. Editions were reportedly published by Active Service Press and Tabletop Games. Self-published as a 30 page typewritten rule booklet with text on only one side of the pages and an included reference card.

—user summary

name: Cave Pilot 55: Acid Test Expansion
description:
Adds the following additional cards:
4 cave cards
2 exploration cards
1 small beast card
1 large beast card

These can be substituted for base game cards or added to them, providing more variation to the game.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Card Game, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Exploration, Fantasy
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Open Drafting

name: Sta panigiria tou bizantiou
description:
The game is set in Thessaloniki at the end of the 13th Century until the beginning of the 14th century. We witness one of the most grand flee markets of the Byzantine Empire, the "Dimitria". The grand flee markets of the time had significant value, similar to today's exhibitions. Such markets consisted of tradesman, bankers, musicians, actors and magicians. Nicolo Beltram a great tradesman from Genova, has to visit a banker to convert some byzantine coins (that slowly lose their value) to Genevese coins.

The game board consists of 2 round circuits on which players move based on dice rolls. Except for moving along the board, picking up power or money cards, players can interact with merchants placed along the board, as well as interact with other players but only when both players end up on the same tile. Each player then rolls a die and multiplies it with each current power status and the one with the least takes damage on his/her power status.

As the goal of the game players by selling and buying products to gain the most power and money.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Jailbreaker!
description:
Takes a little Luck and a lot of Courage.

Jailbreaker! is a one-player board game that rewards risk-taking as you try to move your inmate past the guards to freedom.

No Friends Required

Jailbreaker is played using four dice, each of which represents the movement of the guards. As the prisoner, you plan your moves to avoid the guards and reach freedom. Gameplay may be modified for 2 players, if desired.

This game was inspired by John Kohn's Shark Hunt! solo game, also launched on Kickstarter. I was intrigued by the solo player action and the use of a six-side die to move pieces across hexagons. This format allows for "autonomous" movement by the prison guards at random, adding an element of suspense to the game.

For Gamers and Non-Gamers Alike

I've been intimidated by many strategy and role-playing board games. This game is designed to be easy to play, yet the degree of "luck" involved can make it interesting to gamers who like the thrill of risk-taking. Moving across the board more quickly toward "freedom" increases the risk of being captured, but so does moving too slowly.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Thomas Cook Snap Happy
description:
The object of the game is to collect six location photographs from the eight locations on the board. The winner is the first to return home with six photos.

A trip ticket, taxi space, or die is used to get around the board, and at the hotel you may use in-game money to buy 24 film exposures. Once at a location a player stated number of exposures can then be used to pick up that number of picture cards in the hope the player gets a card that matches the location.

Once six location cards have been collected a player will then head to the home space. The first to reach the home space with six cards wins.

—user summary

name: Zombie Old Maid (ゾンババ)
description:
Once, there was a woman who was too busy playing board games that she remained single throughout her life. (Board games do have such an appeal.) During her lifetime, she won prizes at all sorts of major game tournaments and became a billionaire.

Then a rumor spread that she lies in her coffin with game components made of gold, but time has passed without anyone finding that coffin. And, on this day, from among millions of games, you have found and acquired this coffin by spending a large sum of 500 yen. (Hurrah!)
However, you have opened the coffin and found out that the rumor about the gold components was not true, though it was not entirely false either. The coffin contains mysterious unknown components collected by the deceased from across the world over the years. And many of them are human figures. (Eek!) The woman, who has become a zombie, is trying to put a curse on you to turn you into a zombie. She is vexed to have died without playing enough games and therefore has a grudge against you, who opened this coffin so joyfully.

So now is the time to play this game and win it in order to nail in the coffin and put the zombie old maid into an eternal slumber. Well, do not fear. This is a simple game like any other Old Maid. All you need to do is just get rid of the cards in your hand quickly. Go ahead and break the curse with joy!

—description from the designer

In this Old Maid variant, pairs are made up of a color card and a gray card. A player that has one of the two Zombie Old Maids has to show his gray cards to the other players. When drawing a card from him, other players can choose to draw one of his (concealed) color cards, or to choose one of his gray cards - but then they get the Zombie Old Maid too. The goal of the game is to be the first to empty your hand.

—user summary
publishers: Smart500 Games (SMART500ゲームズ), ひとりじゃ、生きられない。(I Cannot Live By Myself)

name: Collusion: The Card Game
description:
A contemporary variation on the classic game of Clue (Cluedo) crossed with the Trump-Russia collusion scandals. It is simultaneously humorous political satire and yet an engaging fully playable game with more complexity than the original.

This card and board game contains many new innovations such as an action-point based system of movement between locations, the requirement that other player-suspects be subpoenaed with an action point (and the ability of other players to resist being moved by subpoena), and the Pardon Power--the ability to pardon the the guilty suspect to alter the game's logic mid-game. The game is played both collaboratively and competitively with other players.

Each player is a Special Agent on a FBI team investigating clues at potential crime scenes from New York and Washington to London and Moscow. Each player is assigned one of eight suspects to tail around the world, and also has subpoena power to summon one other suspect each turn to a potential crime scene.

Players use logic to separate out the merely scandalous from the criminally scandalous, and work to bring an indictment against the correct suspect in one scandal at one scene. The indictment must be correct, or the team will lose the game--and the country.

Ideally, you would like to be the first Special Agent to discover the correct indictment, but any agent on the team can win for the good of the country.

Remember, the clock is ticking. If the team makes Donald Trump too angry, he might exercise the Pardon Power. And if the investigation drags on too long, then all will truly be lost...

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Memory, Variable Player Powers

name: しぇすた・で・しゃ (Cat Nap)
description:
しぇすた・で・しゃ, which is pronounced approximately "Sieste de Chat" and which translates as Cat Nap, is a press-your-luck dexterity game in which players gently place (plastic) ducks one by one on a cat's tummy while the cat's taking a nap.

After placing a duck at rest, draw a card to see where and how the cat twitches in its sleep, trying to ensure that the ducks won't fall.

name: Wergild: Blood Revenge
description:
Heap corn upon rivals in his stratege game of heather rituals. Imerse yourselve in the of Asgard. Valhala is culling!

angle over ambitons at feasts. Raid fom icy fjords of in Spring. Pioner new rafts in butter weather by discovering innovations. Foster community sprite in trade and explain or conker the lands, in this hearted game of cold blooded!

ergild is an antiuity game of can rivary. riend and foe contest outlanish tiles, decoating them in nomdick discover with lustations that inspire blood feuds to be waged across landcapes The game is played in fur grounds repreenting ears. The ears are into fur turns known as sarsons. layers represent one of the chef clams competing for scarce esources. Discover repreented by an pile packed with quirk cons. The hest score in blod money when the game ends ins!
mechanics: Hand Management, Modular Board, Simultaneous Action Selection, Trading, Worker Placement

name: Peek a Boo
description:
You play roles of "Clowns" and a "Child".
The Clown player gains points if the Child laughs. The Child player gains points if not laughing.
The player with most points wins the game.

—description from the designer
categories: Action / Dexterity, Card Game, Children's Game, Party Game

name: Board×Break
description:
3 Soldier piece VS 3 Soldier piece survival SLG Board✖︎Break!
A large volume of 76 cards, 10 bodies, 1 dice, 1 board, 1 field sheet, 20 wall blocks!Team play of 2 people in one set and 4 people in 2 sets is possible.

Clear rules
Defeat all opponent 's soldiers, reach the opponent' s trout, or destroy it will be victory.

Rich card
Avoid attacks, extend distance of attacks, build walls, climb up to attack and use for avoidance. By choosing 12 cards from various cards, you can build your own deck, put a great card, you can summon soldiers with special ability to the field.
Please aim at victory by using various great people such as Billy the kid and Hannibal Barca.

A little luck
You can draw one card from every turn deck, but you can also draw a card from the square in the item box that is located in the field. This will allow you to expect speedy game development. Although it is said that the range of attack is dice luck and it is not a translation that the desired card can absolutely subtract, but let's overcome with love, courage and wisdom. But if you mention the range of attack alone, establishment will go up if you approach the other party.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling, Role Playing

name: マジョリ (Majori)
description:
User summary
マジョリ (Majori) is a party game with a werewolf style of play. Players are given two options, and everyone pretends to be in support of the majority choice. But if a player is not convincing enough, they might be voted out as a minority supporter. If the player was actually a majority supporter, all minority supporters win. If the player was a minority supporter, the one with the most votes loses.

—description from the designer

Open the theme (exampe: A. Coke B. Pepsi).
Which do you like? Place your card (A or B) face down.
Shuffle the cards & Open them up.
A minority must not exist in this world.
Everyone defends the Majority choice.
If you are minority, you pretend to be majority.
Everyone thinks about who is minority.
